0.text:
You may have heard about the battle of Arnhem,
or you may have seen the film a Bridge Too

3.text:
Far. You may think you know what happened
and what went wrong. Think again. In this

7.text:
series, we’re going to look at as much of
the Market Garden Operation as we can, even

12.text:
the bits other documentaries leave out. We
will dispel the myths that surround this Operation

17.text:
and find out who exactly was to blame for
its failure. In the coming videos, we’ll

26.text:
be covering the entire Operation, which was
not only the biggest airborne assault of all

30.text:
time, but was also the last major defeat for
the British military. It remains a controversial

35.text:
operation. Somehow an all-but defeated German
army clawed their way to victory, stopping

41.text:
the Allies from crossing the Rhine and winning
the war by Christmas. Today, we’re going

44.text:
to focus on the plan, since it’s a plan
which has since been deemed “rotten” and

49.text:
badly executed. But was it really that bad
a plan?

51.text:
The situation by late 1944 for the Germans
was desperate. Nazi Germany had conquered

56.text:
most of Europe in the early days of World
War II, but by 1944, was on the backfoot.

61.text:
The Wehrmacht (or German Army) was decisively
beaten in the East by the Soviets at battles

66.text:
like Stalingrad and Kursk and annihilated
during Operation Bagration. In the South,

71.text:
the Allies had defeated the Germans in the
Desert and were slowly working their way up

75.text:
the Italian peninsular. And in the West, the
Allies had landed in Normandy, had crushed

79.text:
the Germans in the Falaise pocket, liberated
Paris and were now on their way towards Germany.

85.text:
It seemed to most Allied commanders that the
German Army was thoroughly beaten. The Third

89.text:
Reich was about to fall. It was all just a
question of time.

93.text:
Since Normandy, Supreme Allied Commander of
the Allied Expeditionary Force - Eisenhower

96.text:
- had been in charge. Knowing that the Germans
were thinned out after Falaise, Eisenhower

101.text:
prefered a broad front strategy. That is,
by marching his Armies forward on all fronts,

106.text:
so the Germans would have to spread out their
weakened forces and would be overwhelmed by

110.text:
sheer weight of numbers. But supply and logistical
issues soon became a problem. Armies require

115.text:
supplies and fuel if they are to keep on advancing,
and Allied logistics couldn’t keep up with

120.text:
the demand of supplying all the Armies at
the same time. The result? Allied Armies stopped

125.text:
dead in their tracks in late August and early
September 1944.

129.text:
This gave British Field Marshal Montgomery
the chance he’d been waiting for. Monty,

134.text:
experienced in the African Desert and commander
of the Allied forces in the initial stages

138.text:
of the Normandy landings, believed that he
had a plan that could knock out the Germans

142.text:
with a decisive blow if he was given logistical
priority. In his mind, the British could bypass

149.text:
the German Siegfried Line, cross the Rhine
river in September, then race into Germany’s

155.text:
industrial heartland, the Ruhr. He believed
he could win the war by Christmas.

159.text:
Facing logistical problems and knowing that
fighting through the Siegfried Line would

165.text:
be challenging, Eisenhower gave the green
light, and Operation Market Garden was born.

169.text:
Monty’s plan was to drive XXX Corps (a British
Tank and Mobile infantry force) over the bridges

174.text:
of the lower Rhine river and thrust deep into
Germany. That was the Garden part of the plan.

179.text:
But of course Bridges would be no use if the
Germans had a chance to destroy them, so the

184.text:
Bridges had to be secured for the tanks in
advance. And there were several bridges in

188.text:
the area to capture intact if this operation
was to have any chance of success.

193.text:
Therefore, three and a half Airborne Divisions
(a total of 33,971 men) would land on Day

200.text:
1 behind enemy lines to secure both the bridges
and the road to Arnhem. The American 101st

206.text:
Airborne division would land at Eindhoven,
the American 82nd would land at Nijmegen,

209.text:
and the British 1st Airborne Division, supported
by the Polish 1st Independent Airborne Brigade,

215.text:
would land at Arnhem. This was the Market
part of the plan. With a carpet of Airborne

220.text:
troops to secure the route, XXX Corps would
simply cross the secured bridges and ride

224.text:
off to victory! But the bridges had to be
secure - without them, the plan would fail

229.text:
- they were the priority of this Operation.
So this was two operations in one. Operation

235.text:
Market, and Operation Garden. And together
they make Operation Market Garden. Sounds

240.text:
simple… right? It is until you realise there
was another element to the plan not often

244.text:
mentioned. Once the British tanks were over
the Rhine at Arnhem, another Division - the

250.text:
52nd Lowland Infantry Division would be flown
in by air on the fifth day, after Deeland

255.text:
Airfield had been captured. Yes, this wasn’t
an Operation aimed at capturing Arnhem bridge,

260.text:
it went on beyond that. The tanks were meant
to get all the way to Zuiderzee, the shallow

264.text:
bay that juts into the Netherlands. Now, the
reason you don’t hear about this part of

268.text:
the Operation much, is because (spoiler alert)
it didn’t happen. But that was the true

273.text:
goal of Market Garden.
In charge of the Airborne part of the plan

276.text:
was Lieutenant General Sir Arthur Montague
Boy Frederick Browning. This was the father

282.text:
of the British airborne forces, and was the
one who said I think we might be going a bridge

287.text:
too far… well, he may have said that. Nobody
really knows, but he had the task of making

291.text:
Operation Market a success, and that wasn’t
going to be easy.

295.text:
Landing troops behind enemy lines sounds great,
until you consider two things:

300.text:
Paratroopers rely on the element of surprise
to disorientate and confuse the enemy so that

305.text:
they can secure their objective before the
enemy knows what’s happening. So if surprise

308.text:
is lost or they fail to act quickly enough,
they lose their biggest asset.

311.text:
They’re weak. They’re dropped behind enemy
lines, are lightly armed and supplied by the

316.text:
air, so if they’re not relieved in a matter
of days there’s a good chance they’ll

320.text:
be overwhelmed.
Speed is therefore, imperative. The paratroopers

324.text:
have to take their objectives quickly, and
the tanks have to relieve them quickly. It’s

328.text:
worth bearing this in mind as we consider
that cracks began to appear in the plan right

332.text:
from the beginning. For starters, Operation
Garden wasn’t going to be easy. Commanded

336.text:
by Sir Brian Horrocks, XXX Corps would have
one road to drive up. One road. An entire

343.text:
corps, one road. That’s a logistical nightmare.
But considering the enemy could easily counterattack

349.text:
from the sides and cut the road at any point,
plus they had to drive 60 miles just to reach

354.text:
Arnhem… I hope you can see the problem here.
Even if all things went smoothly, it would

358.text:
take at least two to three days for XXX Corps
to get to the British at Arnhem. That’s

362.text:
assuming all the bridges would be taken intact.
If the Germans managed to hold or destroy

367.text:
a bridge or two, it could take even longer.
The issue of delay is compounded when you

372.text:
realise there weren’t enough transport planes
to deliver all three and a bit airborne divisions

376.text:
at the same time. This would mean they would
have to be dropped over a period of three

380.text:
days, because the RAF also refused to fly
in more than one lift per day for fear of

385.text:
exhausting their pilots. Apart from the fact
that this would weaken the strength of the

389.text:
initial landings and compromise the paratrooper’s
element of surprise, it also meant that … potentially

395.text:
... not all the bridges could be secured on
the first day. If some of the bridges aren’t

398.text:
taken, and if XXX Corps is delayed, the Operation
fails and the British at Arhem are doomed.

404.text:
General Gavin of the American 82nd Airborne
Division who was dropping in at Nijmegen decided

408.text:
that he simply didn’t have enough troops
on the first day to take all his objectives.

413.text:
He wanted to take the bridges from both ends
at once, but without enough troops on the

417.text:
ground this wasn’t possible. He also feared
an attack from the Reichswald… a forest

422.text:
that was within the borders of Germany, and
he believed there were a lot of Germans in

426.text:
there ready to counter attack. In his mind,
he would have to pull forces away to capture

430.text:
the heights at Groesbeek, in order to secure
his position against the Reichswald rather

435.text:
than send troops to take the Nijmegen Bridge.
This meant they wouldn’t be able to start

438.text:
their attack on the Nijmegen Bridge until
later in the day, or until reinforcements

443.text:
arrived on the second day. The element of
surprise would be lost, and it was likely

447.text:
that the Germans would have time to react,
dig in and prepare their defenses at the Nijmegen

451.text:
Bridge. Not good.
To make matters worse, the 101st Airborne

455.text:
had to take five bridges on the first day.
5. Lead by Maxwell D. Taylor, the 101st would

461.text:
drop as close to the bridges as they could
to take them as quickly as possible. This

465.text:
would give them the best chance of taking
the bridges, but with 5 to take… chances

469.text:
are, they wouldn’t take them all. This,
and the problems at Nijmegen and the lack

473.text:
of transports meant that, there was a big
chance that there was going to be a delay

477.text:
in reaching Arnhem.
At first glance however, the British at Arnhem

482.text:
seemed to have the least amount of trouble
- they only had one bridge to take (well two,

486.text:
but one main one). Yet it wasn’t as simple
as that. The RAF refused to drop the paratroopers

491.text:
near to the bridge because of that heavy Anti
Air cover over Arnhem, and because the ground

497.text:
south of the bridge was believed to be too
marshy for a landing (although good enough

501.text:
for the Polish airborne coming a few days
later).

506.text:
Major General Roy Urquhart was commander of
the British 1st Airborne Division. Urquhart

510.text:
had never commanded paratroopers before, and
believed that once he was on the ground it

515.text:
was basically going to be the same as any
other infantry battle. No. Paratroopers need

520.text:
to get to their objectives quickly and sit
tight for relief. Essentially, once you take

525.text:
your objective, you’re not attacking, you’re
defending. So perhaps Urquhart was the wrong

530.text:
man for the job? Either way, due to pressure
from the RAF and the US Airforce, Urquhart

535.text:
was forced to land 8 miles to 13 miles away
from the bridge. Yes, 8 to 13 miles away.

541.text:
Not only was there a real chance that the
vital element of surprise be lost, but also

546.text:
the British paras landing on day one would
need to hold the Landing Zones for subsequent

551.text:
waves of paratroopers, meaning that only a
portion of the British paras landing on day

555.text:
one would actually strike towards Arnhem Bridge.
And the British would also need to hold onto

559.text:
a huge area, which realistically they’d
struggle to hold with the entire division.

564.text:
To be fair to Urquhart, he did request for
his troops to be landed nearer to the bridge,

568.text:
such as south of Arnhem (which was again,
good enough for the Polish Brigade coming

572.text:
later but not for anyone on Day 1). Unknown
to Urquhart during the early planning stage,

578.text:
when briefed a few days before the battle,
officers of 1st Parachute Battalion actually

583.text:
volunteered to land on the town of Arnhem
itself rather than land miles away from the

588.text:
bridge, but in the end Air Vice-Marshal Hollinghurst
refused Urquhart’s request and the landing

594.text:
zones remained many miles from Arnhem. The
reason for this was the fear of anti-air batteries

598.text:
over Arnhem. The RAF and the US Airforce thought
they’d take excessive losses if they landed

603.text:
near the city. Urquhart has taken the blame
over the years for the fact that the landing

606.text:
zones were far from the bridge. In reality,
that decision wasn’t his. It’s often been

611.text:
argued that Urquhart should have insisted
on closer landing zones, but the fact remains

616.text:
that it didn’t happen. The British would
land 8 to 13 miles away from the bridge.

621.text:
Of course the British could rely on the Polish
1st Independent Parachute Brigade as reinforcements

627.text:
who would hopefully arrive on Day 3. Yes,
it was no surprise that General Sosabowski,

633.text:
commander of the Polish Brigade, had had misgivings
about this AND the previous proposed operation,

638.text:
operation comet (which was basically similar
to this one, but with less troops). You see,

642.text:
the airborne units had been told to prepare
for battle time and time again over the last

646.text:
few months, only to have plans cancelled last
minute. This not only affected morale, but

650.text:
gave their commanders an eagerness to get
into battle that may have clouded their judgement

655.text:
during the planning of the Market Operation.
General Sosabowski was more accepting of the

660.text:
Market Garden plan because it was better than
the previous one, although it clearly wasn’t

665.text:
perfect. His Polish Brigade would land south
of Arnhem on Day 3, when the element of surprise

671.text:
was lost days before.
It was bad enough for the brigades landing

674.text:
on Day 2. But the eagerness to get into battle
felt by all the Officers and troops is perhaps

679.text:
why the Operation went ahead anyway. And is
also why vital intelligence reports about

684.text:
the existence of German tanks in the area
were ignored. Now tanks could overwhelm the

690.text:
lightly armed paratroopers and threaten the
whole operation. Although a lot of the German

695.text:
units in the Arnhem area were of dubious combat
quality, they did have two rather depleted

701.text:
SS Panzer Divisions in the area. The 9th and
10th SS Panzer Divisions to be exact. Both

707.text:
veteran units with elite soldiers and tanks.
And yet, these intelligence reports were dismissed

710.text:
by Lieutenant General Frederick Browning - the
man in charge of the whole airborne operation

715.text:
- because he didn’t want to cancel the mission
with only two days remaining before it began.

721.text:
Browning also believed that the Germans were
already defeated so these tanks were probably

726.text:
few in number and would be slow to react.
So he didn’t warn Urquhart or any of the

731.text:
British paratroopers of the possibility of
their being two SS Panzer Divisions in the

735.text:
area, which meant the paras didn’t take
as many anti-tank weapons and ammunition as

739.text:
they could have. Oh, and Browning decided
that his corps headquarters would be airlifted

743.text:
into the Nijmegen sector on day one using
a staggering 38 aircraft and extra gliders

748.text:
on top of that, all of which were taken from
the British allocation of transport aircraft

753.text:
- who were already starved of transport aircraft
as priority had been given to the Americans.

758.text:
Oh, and the decision was taken not to support
the air transports or the paratroopers on

763.text:
the ground with ground attack aircraft. This
meant that the Germans would be able to move

766.text:
freely in day-light without fear of being
attacked from the air - something they hadn’t

770.text:
been able to do in Normandy. The Germans could
reinforce their troops as and when they liked,

774.text:
a fact that would prove disastrous as the
battle progressed.

777.text:
Despite having two understrength SS Panzer
divisions in the area, overall the Germans

782.text:
facing the Market Garden Operation were weak
and were forced to fill the front with rag

788.text:
tag units. Including units like the ‘eyes
and ears battalions’ who consisted of men

793.text:
who had disabilities that had prevented them
from fighting, until now. By this point in

797.text:
the war, Germany was scraping the bottom of
the manpower and material barrel, however,

801.text:
they were well led. Field Marshal Model, Commander
in Chief of Army Group B, coincidently had

808.text:
his headquarters in the Hartenstein Hotel
near to the British Landing zones. He was

813.text:
an experienced leader, having earned nicknames
such as “Master of Defence”, “Lion of

819.text:
Defence”, the “Saviour of the Eastern
Front”, and the “Fuhrer’s Fireman”

824.text:
(because he’s constantly putting out fires,
or plugging holes in the front). In the defensive

830.text:
battle that followed, Model was the right
man for the job.

835.text:
As was Kurt Student, Commander of the 1st
Fallschirmjaeger Army. Fallshirmjaeger were

841.text:
German Paratroopers and in the days prior
to the Allied airborne assault, Student had

846.text:
been ordered to ‘Collect all available units
together and build a new front’. This he

850.text:
had done (and these units weren’t all elite
paratroopers) but it’s important to note

854.text:
that Student was an experienced leader and
had directed some of the first opposed paratrooper

859.text:
landings in history. You have to remember
that paratrooper operations had only begun

864.text:
in 1940 so it remained a new concept even
by 1944. Lessons were still needed to be learnt

870.text:
about how to properly use paratroopers in
combat, but it was the Germans who had pioneered

875.text:
their early use. Student had been the Commander
of the Fallshirmjaeger since the early days.

876.text:
In charge of ii ss panzer corps was Wilhelm
bittrich. Harmel was in command of 10th ss

883.text:
panzer division and harzer was in command
of the ninth. All of them experienced commanders

889.text:
who'd proven themselves in previous campaigns,
including at Normandy in Operations like Epsom

894.text:
and good wood.
Good commanders commanding ad hoc forces is

897.text:
what the British and Americans were facing.
However, it’s worth noting that although

901.text:
the two SS Panzer Divisions together totalled
maybe 7000 men at most (about 30% of what

907.text:
they should have been) the entire II SS Panzer
Corps had spent a good 15 months performing

913.text:
anti-paratroop landing training. The Corp
had been founded to stop the Normandy landings,

916.text:
including paratroop landings, and these training
exercises were fresh in their minds. Essentially,

919.text:
the paratroopers were landing against an enemy
who knew how to deal with them.

923.text:
So this is where we stand on the eve of battle.
Three landing zones, one road, and an underestimated

927.text:
enemy. The plan has the potential to end the
war by Christmas, but it isn’t flawless.

933.text:
I’ll leave you with a question - how rotten
was this plan? And do you think it was doomed

938.text:
to fail from the start? Comment below and
let me know. Next time, we’ll see what happens

942.text:
on Day One, so don’t forget to like and
subscribe if you haven’t done already. Thanks

951.text:
for watching, thanks for subscribing, bye
for now.The largest airborne operation in

962.text:
history begins on a Sunday. September 17th,
1944. The first Allied paratroopers and gliders

970.text:
descend in Holland in the early afternoon.
Thousands of men land as many as sixty miles

976.text:
behind enemy lines. And despite the fact that
the battle ahead would last nine days, it

981.text:
was in the first vital hours of the Operation
that the outcome of the whole battle, and

985.text:
the lives of thousands of soldiers and civilians
on both sides, would be decided.

992.text:
Intro graphic
Last time we saw how the Allied battle plan

998.text:
wasn’t without its flaws, and how the Germans
weren’t as ill prepared as the Allied Generals

1003.text:
believed. And as the battle begins, the question
we have to ask ourselves is … did the Allies

1008.text:
make efficient use of the first vital hours
of the operation? It’s the middle of the

1013.text:
day, there’s plenty of light and despite
a few accidents, no serious casualties are

1018.text:
sustained on the drops. The element of surprise
works in the Allies’ favour. Taking advantage

1023.text:
of German confusion, most of the Allied objectives
are taken quickly within a few hours. Most.

1030.text:
The American 101st Airborne Division lands
north of Eindhoven and secures most of its

1034.text:
target bridges. But as the 2nd Battalion of
the 506th Regiment (which included Easy Company

1039.text:
from the Band of Brothers Series) approached
the bridge at Son, an 88 and nearby German

1044.text:
sentries managed to delay the paratroopers
long enough to blow the bridge. The Americans

1049.text:
were just 50 metres from the bridge when it
blew up in their faces. Equally as concerning,

1053.text:
the 502nd Regiment fought their way through
to the bridge at Best, which the Germans also

1057.text:
managed to blow before it fell into American
hands. So the 101st failed to capture a bridge

1062.text:
on the canal at the southern end of their
sector. XXX Corps can’t cross a canal without

1067.text:
a bridge, so when they eventually arrive,
there’s going to be delays as they’re

1071.text:
going to have to build a replacement bridge.
And if that wasn’t bad enough, a glider

1074.text:
from the 101st crashed near Student’s headquarters
and plans for the entire Operation, Operation

1081.text:
Market Garden, were in Student’s hands by
around 3pm that same day. Day One.

1088.text:
But the 101st weren’t the only ones having
trouble. The 82nd landing near Nijmegen did

1093.text:
secure the heights at Groesbeek, the Heumen
bridge and the bridge at Grave. Browning had

1099.text:
also flown in and now set up his headquarters
on the Groesbeek Heights. I’m mentioning

1103.text:
that because Gavin and Browning had both decided
the Groesbeek heights were the priority for

1108.text:
the Operation and had to be taken. And they
were taken, because there were literally no

1113.text:
Germans there. As a result, a good portion
of 82nd Airborne were just sat on the Groesbeek

1118.text:
Heights shelling the nearby woods (the Reichswald)
because a sizeable German counter-attacking

1124.text:
force was believed to be in there. Time was
ticking down to take what was the REAL priority

1129.text:
- the road bridge at Nijmegen. Now, the 1st
Battalion, commanded by Lieutenant Shields

1133.text:
Warren, had been ordered to take Nijmegen
bridge that day. However, Warren was first

1138.text:
ordered to secure some of the suburbs of Nijmegen
and prepare them for defense, which took him

1143.text:
most of the day. So early on, things weren’t
looking so good at Nijmegen either. If the

1148.text:
82nd fail to take the Nijmegen Bridge, there’s
no way XXX Corps can build a bridge over the

1153.text:
Waal. Nijmegen Bridge has to be taken. But
it isn’t.

1156.text:
At Arnhem, the British land in fields surrounded
by woods. This works in their favour as it

1162.text:
prevented the Germans seeing exactly what
the British were up to. But it also didn’t

1166.text:
work in their favour, as they were 8 to 13
miles away from their main objective, Arnhem

1171.text:
Bridge. But General Urquhart had prepared
for this. Knowing that it would take hours

1177.text:
to fight their way over several miles of enemy
held territory, he decided to send 1st Airborne’s

1183.text:
Reconnaissance Squadron, supplied with Jeeps,
ahead. The idea was to send the jeeps ahead

1189.text:
to the Arnhem road bridge in a coup-de-main
(or surprise) attack, then wait for reinforcements

1194.text:
from the rest of the division to arrive. Neither
trained to use them, nor were they meant to

1199.text:
be used for anything other than reconnaissance,
this lightly armed and unarmoured force wouldn’t

1204.text:
last long in a major firefight, but it might
be able to slip behind enemy lines and might

1209.text:
be able to get to the bridge quickly.
However, Sepp Krafft’s SS Training and Replacement

1214.text:
Battalion was one of the closest units to
the British landing zones, and seeing the

1218.text:
paratroopers land, he decided to quickly form
a blocking line near Wolfheze and to scout

1223.text:
out the British positions to gain vital information…
because observation was obscured by the trees.

1228.text:
Krafft wasn’t sure what the British were
trying to achieve but his line would cause

1233.text:
the British some problems in those first vital
hours. It was the Northern end of this blocking

1238.text:
line that the British Reconnaissance squadron
drove into, barely minutes after the line

1242.text:
had been formed. The small force of jeeps
was stopped by heavy machine gun fire and

1246.text:
even a flamethrower attack. They then tried
to advance by foot, but were driven back.

1252.text:
The first attack towards Arnhem had failed.
Fitch’s 3rd Battalion marched along the

1256.text:
Utrechtseweg, south of most of Krafft’s
positions towards Arnhem. Unfortunately for

1261.text:
Fitch, General Urquhart accompanied the Battalion,
and slowed things down. Lieutenant Cleminson’s

1267.text:
platoon took out a German car... this one…
and it was only after the war that they found

1272.text:
out it was General Friedrich Kussin, Arnhem’s
commandant who had only just finished briefing

1277.text:
Krafft on the situation. Despite this success,
3rd Battalion got embroiled in fighting Krafft’s

1284.text:
Battalion, including an incident where General
Urquhart himself was shot at by machine guns

1289.text:
and mortar fire.
Dobie’s 1st Battalion was to take the route

1291.text:
that started along the Ede-Arnhem railway,
but hearing reports of tanks ahead, Dobie

1297.text:
chose to circle north of the route instead.
This had the benefit of bypassing Krafft’s

1303.text:
blocking line, but he soon became caught in
fighting in the wooded areas north of Wolfheze.

1308.text:
The German unit was a hastily formed Kampfgruppe,
or battlegroup (which we’ll explain later),

1314.text:
named after it’s commander ‘Weber’.
Consisting of ninety or so Luftwaffe signallers,

1319.text:
and despite being poorly armed and inexperienced,
they attacked the paras as best they could.

1323.text:
They didn’t do a lot of damage, but they
did cause a delay.

1326.text:
To the South, Lieutenant-Colonel John Frost’s
2nd Battalion had been given the dual task

1331.text:
of taking the Arnhem Rail Bridge and the main
objective… the Road bridge. Frost’s men

1337.text:
got into combat almost immediately, destroying
a small column of vehicles, probably a reconnaissance

1341.text:
company from Krafft’s Battalion, but was
quick to get going towards the bridges. Bypassing

1346.text:
the important Heveadorp ferry (capable of
transporting troops across the Rhine, but

1351.text:
overlooked in the initial planning), they
reached Oosterbeek by 6pm and overwhelmed

1356.text:
the token German resistance there. Detaching
Lieutenant Barry’s 9th Platoon supported

1360.text:
by 8th Platoon with orders to take the Rail
bridge, Barry lead a section of nine men onto

1365.text:
the north end of the bridge itself. He thought
he could take the entire bridge, but as he

1369.text:
got to the centre of the bridge above the
water, the bridge exploded. Luckily, none

1374.text:
of the men with him were killed by the explosion,
but the Rail bridge was destroyed. No matter,

1379.text:
this wasn’t the main objective. The main
objective was the Arnhem Road bridge. Now,

1383.text:
it had taken three hours for 2 Para to get
to this point. The German guards at the rail

1388.text:
bridge had had plenty of time to prepare their
explosives, so the chances of the Road bridge

1393.text:
being there when they got to it.... They had
to go on. Frost’s Battalion continued towards

1397.text:
Arnhem.
Shortly before the destruction of the Rail

1399.text:
bridge however, Field Marshal Model, German
Commander in Chief of Army Group B, fled his

1403.text:
headquarters at the Hartenstein Hotel for
fear of being captured. Interestingly, it’s

1408.text:
claimed that Model wrongly came to the conclusion
that the British landed in Holland purely

1413.text:
to capture him! There’s no evidence of that.
But it is true that he fled the hotel, and

1417.text:
having assessed the situation, at 17:30 he
(and the staff of IISS Corps) issue the first

1424.text:
and perhaps most important order to the German
units in the Arnhem-Nijmegen area. Immediate

1430.text:
counter-attacks were to take place, with 9th
SS Panzer Division to concentrate against

1435.text:
the British at Arnhem, and the 10th SS Panzer
Division to drive to Nijmegen, secure the

1441.text:
bridge there and prevent any relief from getting
to the British at Arnhem. At the same time,

1445.text:
Student’s 1st Fallschirmjäger Army was
to combat XXX Corps’ advance and the 101st

1451.text:
Airborne at Eindhoven.
This was a significant order. The Germans

1454.text:
had decided to halt the relieving forces at
Nijmegen. If they did that, the British at

1460.text:
Arnhem would be trapped miles behind enemy
lines... and doomed.

1464.text:
At 18:00 Krafft suspected that he’d been
outflanked (he had). Fearing the possibility

1471.text:
of encirclement, he withdrew his force, which
in turn allowed elements of 3rd Battalion

1475.text:
to continue towards the bridge. Having delayed
3rd Para, Krafft’s force retreated to the

1481.text:
Dreyenseweg and helped reinforce a new battle
group that had been hastily set up there,

1485.text:
Kampfgruppe Spindler.
The Germans had practiced a new type of unit

1489.text:
organisation, called Kampfgruppen. This was
an ad hoc formation, which could be created

1494.text:
or disbanded depending on circumstances. It’s
basically a makeshift unit usually cobbled

1500.text:
together from bits of other units and then
given a leader and a task. Experienced and

1504.text:
decorated in both the Iron Cross and the German
Cross in Gold, SS Lieutenant-Colonel Spindler,

1510.text:
commander of the 9th SS Panzer Division’s
Artillery regiment, pulled in as many units

1515.text:
under his command as possible, even units
without guns. But he managed, by the evening

1520.text:
of the 17th, to assemble a force of infantry,
half tracks and self propelled guns, and possibly

1526.text:
even some tank destroyers and Mark IV tanks.
He decided, perhaps off his own initiative,

1531.text:
to form a blocking line to prevent the British
from getting into the center of Arnhem. Spindler

1535.text:
is a very significant figure in this Operation,
who we will see again and again as the battle

1540.text:
progresses.
Frost and 2nd Battalion was lucky enough to

1543.text:
bypass Spindler’s line before it solidified.
Following the bend in the Rhine and despite

1549.text:
having to detach a company at Den Brink to
deal with the German machine guns there, 2nd

1554.text:
Battalion marched into Arnhem. As they moved
through the streets, German vehicles screeched

1559.text:
across the Arnhem Road bridge heading south.
Commanded by SS Captain Viktor Graebner, the

1563.text:
9th SS Reconnaissance Battalion headed towards
Nijmegen. Viktor Graebner was another significant

1570.text:
figure at Arnhem and we’ll return to him
again next time. The point is that only a

1574.text:
handful of guards were guarding Arnhem Road
Bridge. Frost reached the Road Bridge at 20:00,

1579.text:
followed shortly by 1st Brigade headquarters.
They had covered seven or eight miles in five

1584.text:
hours. The bridge guards were in a pillbox
on the bridge itself, so 2 Para dug into positions

1589.text:
beneath the bridge and waited for 3rd Battalion
and the Reconnaissance Squadron, which ominously

1594.text:
hadn’t yet arrived.
That’s because, facing Kampfgruppe Spindler’s

1597.text:
determined defensive line, 3rd Battalion had
decided to dig in near Oosterbeek and no further

1603.text:
progress was made that evening. Only C Company,
which had gone north of Krafft’s position

1607.text:
managed to fight their way to the bridge after
a violent clash in Arnhem itself, resulting

1612.text:
in only forty-five men reaching Frost’s
position. 1st Battalion’s commander, Dobie,

1617.text:
received word via radio that 2nd Battalion
had reached the bridge and needed reinforcements.

1622.text:
He decided to abandon the idea of fighting
to reach the North of Arnhem and to just get

1627.text:
to the bridge. He turned South East and fought
throughout the night, losing over a hundred

1632.text:
men and only got halfway to their objective
before they too were stopped by Kampfgruppe

1637.text:
Spindler. Spindler had stopped two of the
three Battalions from getting to the Arnhem

1642.text:
Road Bridge on Day One, and this achievement
is even more admirable when you consider that

1646.text:
his force hadn’t existed that morning. By
the late evening of the 17th, another kampfgruppen

1651.text:
named “Harder” after its commander (who
was, to slightly complicate things, was under

1655.text:
the command of Spindler), moved into Western
Arnhem and cut off Frost’s troops from the

1661.text:
rest of 1st Airborne. There was now no way
any more British paratroopers were getting

1666.text:
to Arnhem that evening.
In all, around 750 men reached the Road Bridge

1670.text:
at Arnhem. Almost all of 2nd Battalion, a
45 man unit from 3rd Battalion, Brigade Headquarters

1677.text:
as well as a few more men from other smaller
units had made it. They had with them only

1683.text:
limited stocks of food and ammunition. They’d
gone unnoticed by the twenty or so Germans

1688.text:
manning the pillbox on the bridge, and a couple
of attempts to knock it out failed, until

1692.text:
a 6-pounder and a flamethrower were brought
up. Missing the bunker, the flamethrower hit

1698.text:
the ammunition and petrol storage hut behind
it and a large explosion covered the bridge

1703.text:
in flame that would burn throughout the night.
Later, a convoy of German lorries carrying

1709.text:
ammunition supplies attempted to cross the
burning bridge. Yes, the flames exploded the

1716.text:
ammunition they carried and this only added
to the inferno. Another convoy (a V-2 rocket

1721.text:
unit) was also ambushed on the Arnhem side,
and several men taken prisoner, although the

1726.text:
British didn’t realise they were V-2 rocket
operators, which meant the V-2 rocket operators

1732.text:
survived the battle. But overall, part of
the British paratroop force had reached their

1736.text:
objective and now just had to wait for relief
by XXX Corps.

1739.text:
So where were the tanks? XXX Corps had to
go thirteen miles between their start point

1745.text:
and the city of Eindhoven. Between Eindhoven
and them was the German front-line. After

1750.text:
an artillery barrage, the lead tanks had moved
barely 30 minutes before ...quote... all hell

1752.text:
broke lose. German infantry and guns hit them
from the woods on either side of the road,

1755.text:
brewing-up nine tanks in the immediate ambush.
The British deployed infantry and Typhoons

1760.text:
from the RAF to deal with the Germans, and
the infantry went in to clear the enemy positions,

1765.text:
finally allowing XXX Corps to continue. By
this point, the Germans were reacting to the

1770.text:
attack, sending in five battalions to try
halt the advance. The whole day was spent

1776.text:
fighting one new regiment after another that
British intelligence officers were surprised

1780.text:
even existed. And by the end of the day, XXX
Corps had gone only eight miles from their

1786.text:
starting point. There were another fifty-six
miles to Arnhem, a bridge at Son to rebuild,

1793.text:
and still many more Germans between them.
At least all the bridges were taken on Day

1796.text:
One, and those that weren’t could be rebuilt.
Oh, except for one. Nijmegen bridge was still

1802.text:
in enemy hands and the 82nd Airborne had yet
to make an attack on it. Finally, at 8pm,

1808.text:
Warren was able to send two rifle companies
from 1st Battalion towards the bridge. A and

1813.text:
B Companies attacked into Nijmegen, but B
Company got lost along the way, so A Company

1819.text:
went on alone. Yes, only one Company was attacking
one of the main objectives in the 82nd’s

1825.text:
sector, and it was many hours after the paras
had landed. As they approached the bridge

1830.text:
(which at this point was still guarded by
only a handful of Germans), a German convoy

1836.text:
of reinforcements from the North arrived.
It was an entire infantry battalion from the

1841.text:
10th SS Panzer Division, supported by a company
of engineers and Viktor Graebner’s Reconnaissance

1847.text:
Battalion from 9th SS Panzer Division. The
fighting began, but it was heavily in the

1853.text:
German’s favour. B Company arrived later
in the night but they too found the situation

1857.text:
hopeless. The Americans did manage to capture
and destroy the firing mechanism for the bridge,

1862.text:
meaning the Germans weren’t able to blow
the bridge (not that they were planning to

1866.text:
anyway), but they were outgunned and outnumbered
now. The Germans even managed to counter-attack

1871.text:
and surround a unit in the post office, who
would stay there surrounded for the next three

1875.text:
days. The 82nd had failed to capture Nijmegen
Bridge.

1879.text:
The entire Operation depended on the capture
of every bridge. Son had been destroyed, but

1885.text:
since it was over a canal, a bailey bridge
could be built in a matter of hours to replace

1890.text:
it. But the bridge at Nijmegen spanned a much
larger body of water and a bailey bridge couldn’t

1896.text:
be built over that. Nijmegen bridge had to
be taken on the first day. And it wasn’t.

1902.text:
So things don’t bode too well for Operation
Market Garden at this early stage, but there

1906.text:
was still hope. If 1st Airborne could fight
their way to Frost at the bridge, if XXX Corps

1911.text:
could make good the delay and reach and repair
Son bridge quickly, and if the 82nd could

1917.text:
somehow capture Nijmegen Road bridge (which
at this point was still a possibility) the

1922.text:
battle could be won, and the war, over by
Christmas. The question is, did the Allies

1928.text:
make efficient use of the first vital hours
of the operation? And who made the worst mistakes

1932.text:
at this early stage? Let me know who you think
it is in the comments below.

1937.text:
We’ll continue the fight tomorrow. But before
we leave, it’s worth mentioning SS Captain

1941.text:
Viktor Graebner one more time. This guy went
everywhere on the 17th. First he had the Knight’s

1947.text:
Cross pinned onto his chest by Divisional
commander Harzer earlier on the 17th (unlike

1952.text:
what Wikipedia says, which is why we don’t
rely on it) Graebner sent units to scout out

1956.text:
positions along the Ede-Arnhem road, he fought
elements of 1st Battalion, and then he drove

1961.text:
across Arnhem bridge at 18:00 - an hour or
two before Frost’s men reached it. At 19:00

1967.text:
he was at Elst, South of Arnhem. And finding
no paratroopers there, he raced to Nijmegen

1972.text:
and found no Americans at Nijmegen either.
Yet within 24 hours of this picture being

1977.text:
taken, Graebner was dead. We’ll find out
why, tomorrow. Thanks for watching, thanks

1983.text:
for subscribing, by for now.At 09:00 hours
on Monday the 18th September 1944, SS Captain

1996.text:
Viktor Graebner, commander of the 9th SS Reconnaissance
Battalion, drives his force across Arnhem

2003.text:
Road Bridge from the south. Perhaps thinking
he could surprise and shock the British paras

2007.text:
into surrender, his half tracks and puma armoured
cars rumbled into view of 2 Para’s positions.

2013.text:
Graebner’s newly earned Knights Cross reminded
him that such tactics had worked before, but

2019.text:
sadly, wouldn’t work this time.
Intro graphic

2026.text:
Yesterday, we saw how the initial landings
had gone smoothly, but then several things

2031.text:
had gone wrong. Frost’s men had failed to
take the Arnhem Rail bridge but had reached

2036.text:
the Arnhem Road Bridge whilst the rest of
the Division floundered around Oosterbeek.

2040.text:
The 82nd had taken most of the bridges except
the vital Nijmegen Bridge, and were busy pounding

2046.text:
the Reichswald. The 101st had taken most of
their objectives except for the bridges at

2051.text:
Best and Son, both of which were destroyed.
But they held the area around Son and could

2056.text:
put a bailey bridge across the canal once
XXX Corps had arrived. And XXX Corps had fought

2060.text:
hard to break through the German crust, which
had been thicker than imagined. They still

2064.text:
hadn’t reached Eindhoven by days end and
they were now behind schedule.

2068.text:
But Day 2 was now upon them, and it started
with a bang as Graebner’s reconnaissance

2074.text:
battalion headed north across the Arnhem Road
bridge. He’d left some Self-Propelled guns

2079.text:
at Nijmegen to help defend there and raced
north to Arnhem, thinking only a handful of

2084.text:
British paras held the north end of the bridge.
He believed a quick attack across the bridge

2089.text:
could dislodge the British from their positions.
Remember, no one knew how many British there

2095.text:
were, and Graebner thought he was facing a
force smaller than his. Not true. His battalion,

2100.text:
consisting of half-tracks, armoured cars and
trucks carrying infantry, drives across the

2105.text:
bridge. Some of Graebner’s vehicles actually
make it all the way across. Things look good,

2111.text:
until one vehicle strikes a British anti-tank
mine, and all hell breaks loose. Concentrated

2116.text:
rifle and machine gun fire from both flanks
riddled the open half tracks, killing crew

2120.text:
and passengers alike. Mortar fire rained down
on the Germans, and grenades were lobbed into

2124.text:
the open hatches of the armoured cars. Chaos
and confusion disrupted the attack, and Graebner

2130.text:
was killed. More vehicles tried in vain to
continue to advance, feeding the defeat, and

2135.text:
it wasn’t until midday that the fighting
finally came to an end. In two hours, 12 vehicles

2140.text:
out of the 22 that had took part in the attack,
burned on the bridge, and the largest concentration

2146.text:
of armoured vehicles in 9th SS Panzer Division
had been cut to pieces.

2150.text:
What this represented was an important change
in the battlefield. Day 1 had been about movement,

2154.text:
capturing objectives quickly by surprise,
but now the fronts were beginning to solidify.

2160.text:
Fluid and daring maneuvers gave way to positional
warfare. Foxholes were dug. Lines were forming.

2166.text:
Positions were taken and fortified. Rapid
attacks weren’t going to bring about victory.

2172.text:
The moment had passed for decisive attacks,
it was now going to be an attritional infantry

2178.text:
slog. Frosts men at the bridge had fought
off Graebner’s attack, but were not in the

2182.text:
best situation. These are the buildings which
they had fortified. Surrounded by Germans

2184.text:
and now short of ammunition, they hoped either
1st Airborne or XXX Corps would reach them

2189.text:
soon. They had to reach them soon.
But by this point, XXX Corps hadn’t even

2193.text:
reached the 101st American Airborne Division
at Eindhoven, fifty miles to the South of

2197.text:
Arnhem. They had a bridge to rebuild at Son,
the bridge at Nijmegen to take, and time was

2203.text:
ticking down. The Germans were now counter-attacking
positions of the 101st, and by the end of

2207.text:
the day, had retaken the bridges at Best and
the Wilhelmina Canal. XXX Corps would reach

2212.text:
the 101st at Eindhoven by 12:30 and would
get to Son in the early evening, where they

2219.text:
found the destroyed bridge. They began to
construct the bailey bridge that would allow

2221.text:
them to continue their advance to Arnhem.
However, the bailey bridge wouldn’t be finished

2227.text:
this day, with the result that XXX Corps was
now behind schedule.

2232.text:
Equally as concerning, 1st Airborne Division
were still miles to the West of Arnhem and

2236.text:
desperately trying to break through to 2nd
Battalion at the Bridge. Before dawn, Fitch’s

2241.text:
3rd Battalion (accompanied by General Urquhart)
moved from Oosterbeek and gained a mile and

2246.text:
a half of ground without much opposition.
However, as they reached the Western suburbs

2251.text:
of Arnhem they were blocked by Kampfgruppe
Spindler. It was at this point that General

2256.text:
Urquhart, himself confused in the street fighting
and trying to go back towards Oosterbeek,

2261.text:
ended up trapped in a house in Western Arnhem.
A self-propelled gun parked itself outside

2267.text:
his position, leaving the whole of 1st Airborne
Division without their leader. Sat with him

2271.text:
was Lathbury, who was in charge of 1st Parachute
Brigade (the units that were fighting towards

2276.text:
the bridge). Without leadership to organise
the attacks, the battalions fighting towards

2281.text:
the bridge struggled to make headway. For
the rest of the day, 3rd Battalion were pinned

2285.text:
down in the street fighting on the outskirts
of Arnhem, making little progress. By the

2290.text:
days end, only around 140 men of 3rd Battalion
were left.

2294.text:
Further back, 1st Battalion had marched through
the night and now were in Oosterbeek. Their

2299.text:
commander, Dobie, was not in contact with
3rd Battalion and assumed they too had gone

2304.text:
on ahead to the bridge. He therefore attempted
to march straight to Arnhem. His troops had

2309.text:
reached the railway embankment at around 05:30,
but suffered casualties. Knowing that his

2314.text:
unit would be useless if it didn’t get to
its objective in one piece, he decided to

2318.text:
avoid fighting and turned south. He linked
up with stragglers from 3rd Battalion and

2322.text:
by about 08:00 they had passed the railway
line. But were then fired upon by Germans

2327.text:
in nearby houses and armoured vehicles at
Den Brink. There was now no other option but

2331.text:
to fight their way forwards, 1st Battalion
(with elements of 3rd Battalion) fought through

2336.text:
sniper and machine gun fire to clear out the
buildings between them and the rest of 3rd

2340.text:
Battalion. But by late afternoon, the exhausted
paras had only just caught up with the remnants

2345.text:
of 3rd Battalion. Despite advanced elements
being only around 800 yards from the bridge,

2350.text:
they would go no further that day.
Back at 1st Airborne Headquarters at the Hartenstein

2354.text:
hotel, things were looking little better.
Lieutenant-Colonel Charles Mackenzie now informed

2360.text:
Brigadier Hicks that he was now in charge
of 1st Airborne, since Urquhart had disappeared.

2366.text:
Urquhart had issued orders that in the event
that himself and Lathbury (who was sat in

2370.text:
the same house Urquhart was) were lost, that
Hicks would be next in line, and then if Hicks

2376.text:
was lost, then Brigadier Hackett would be
in command. So Hicks, hearing reports that

2382.text:
1st and 3rd Battalion were struggling to get
to Frost at the bridge, decided to send the

2386.text:
South Staffords and 11th Battalion of Hackett’s
Brigade to help them - as soon as the second

2392.text:
airlift arrived. Remember, not all of 1st
Airborne had gone in on the first day - 11th

2397.text:
Battalion hadn’t arrived yet, and half the
South Staffords hadn’t arrived either. A

2401.text:
good chunk of 1st Airborne had had to guard
the landing zones for the reinforcements that

2407.text:
were expected… now, but those reinforcements
were delayed for 4 hours. It wasn’t until

2412.text:
the afternoon that the second lift arrived.
So half the South Staffords went to Arnhem

2417.text:
in the morning, taking a similar route as
1st Battalion and managed to catch up to 1st

2422.text:
Battalion later in the day. And when the second
lift did arrive, Brigadier Hicks informed

2426.text:
his (technically) superior in rank Brigadier
Hackett, that his 11th Battalion was being

2431.text:
taken from him and sent off to reinforce the
Arnhem relief attempt. The result : 11th Battalion

2437.text:
sat for at least two hours - but perhaps longer
- outside the Hartenstein Hotel as the two

2442.text:
Brigadiers argued over how 11th Battalion
should best be deployed. Hackett who wasn’t

2448.text:
exactly pleased that his inferior was in charge
of the Division, thought that the situation

2452.text:
was at Arnhem was “untidy” and had not
been informed until now that his own troops

2458.text:
were being taken from him. Ultimately, 11th
Battalion commanded by Lieutenant-Colonel

2462.text:
George Lea, and the second half of the South
Staffords managed to reach the west end of

2467.text:
Arnhem by the closing hours of day 2.
So the situation at Arnhem wasn’t great,

2472.text:
but the good news was that a good portion
of British paras were in the same area and

2476.text:
about to launch an attack that would hopefully
relieve Frost at the Bridge. That attack though

2480.text:
would go in tomorrow.
Further to the south, the 101st were now battling

2484.text:
against several German units. The previous
day had seen only minor skirmishes, but now,

2489.text:
Student was able to pull in new units and
start counter-attacking. Student, as you may

2494.text:
remember, was the leader of the German paratroopers,
the Fallschirmjager, and quote “I knew more

2499.text:
than anybody else that an airborne landing
is at its weakest in the first few hours,

2504.text:
and must be sorted out quickly and determinedly.”
He therefore threw units at the 101st, even

2509.text:
though most were of poor quality, simply because
he wanted to hit the Americans early. At this

2514.text:
point, his men were trainee Fallschirmjaeger
and police units, but he knew that the 15th

2519.text:
Army was arriving from across the Scheldt.
Starting on the evening of the first day,

2522.text:
but really got going on the 18th, Kampfgruppe
Rink, the 59th Infantry Division, and the

2528.text:
Fallschirmjaeger Battalion Ewald, all struck
against the elite American paratroopers. Luckily

2533.text:
for the Allies, the attacks went in piecemeal
and were therefore beaten back, having little

2538.text:
impact overall on this day.
But, Student was able to start pulling in

2542.text:
the 107th Panzer Brigade from Helmond. This
was an entirely different kettle of fish.

2547.text:
Armed with deadly Panther medium tanks and
Panzergrenadier infantry, this force could

2552.text:
overcome the lightly armed American paratroopers.
However, it could only move by night for fear

2556.text:
of Allied air attack, so Student would have
to wait until tomorrow - Day 3 - to use them.

2562.text:
In the middle at Nijmegen, the 82nd successfully
held the Groesbeek Heights overnight against…

2567.text:
no German attacks. But on the morning of the
18th the Germans sent in the 406th Division

2573.text:
to take the Heights. Except the day before,
this division was a division only on paper.

2578.text:
It consisted of a HQ unit and a few training
units. By the 18th, General Scherbening had

2585.text:
cobbled together some inexperienced Luftwaffe,
eyes and ears and artillery units and called

2591.text:
it a “Division”. In reality it was was
little more than four Battalions in strength,

2596.text:
and may have been weaker than that. What is
certain, is that they had few heavy weapons

2600.text:
and many of the soldiers had no practical
infantry training at all. Early on the 18th,

2604.text:
this force attacked the elite American paratroopers
dug in on the Groesbeek Heights, and somehow

2609.text:
managed to take some of the drop zones, killing...
wait for it... 11 Americans and wounding some

2616.text:
more. But at 1 o’clock, the second wave
of American paratroopers dropped from the

2621.text:
skies and coupled with an attack by the paratroopers
already on the ground, the German units were

2626.text:
routed from the field, with the loss of a
1000 men killed or captured. This was the

2632.text:
only serious attack on Groesbeek in the first
few days of the Operation and it had ended

2637.text:
in disaster for the Germans.
A little to the North, a German engineer battalion

2641.text:
of the 10th SS was now running a ferry across
the Pannerden canal. Progress was slow, but

2648.text:
units were steadily getting across and marching
to Nijmegen. Kampfgruppe Henke occupied positions

2654.text:
in and around Hunnerpark, and was now being
reinforced by half tracks and more infantry

2659.text:
who came across the Waal on dinghies, rather
than face fire if they tried to cross the

2665.text:
bridge. German forces found themselves winning,
as Gavin had pulled back some of the paratroopers

2670.text:
to help out at Groesbeek. There was now a
lull in the fighting! The Germans gathered

2675.text:
more forces and Kampfgruppe Reinhold took
up Henke’s old positions as Kampfgruppe

2680.text:
Henke now moved to secure the nearby railway
bridge, which at this point, hadn’t seen

2685.text:
any action at all. Reinhold dug trenches,
almost completely unopposed by the 82nd, 88mm

2691.text:
guns were positioned across the river and
armoured vehicles moved into the city. Mines

2697.text:
were laid, buildings that were in the way
of their defensive plans were demolished.

2701.text:
The center of Nijmegen was now fully in German
hands and they had the entire day to fortify

2707.text:
it.
It’s worth noting at this point that as

2709.text:
Day 2 comes to a close, the situation across
most of the battlefield is stable and in Allied

2715.text:
control. XXX Corps had reached the 101st and
would soon have the bailey bridge up and running.

2719.text:
The 82nd had successfully held the Groesbeek
Heights against a German division that hadn’t

2724.text:
existed the day before and barely existed
even now. And at Arnhem, though the British

2728.text:
hadn’t got many troops to the Bridge, Frosts
men were dug in and potentially, could be

2733.text:
reinforced by the large force of British paras
who were only 800 yards from them.

2737.text:
And yet there was one vital piece of the puzzle
that needed to be grasped. Nijmegen, the only

2743.text:
bridge on Day 2 that still hadn’t been secure
at any point so far. But Nijmegen city was

2748.text:
now a fortress, garrisoned by an ever growing
number of elite German SS Panzergrenadiers.

2754.text:
82nd Airborne had failed to take this crucial
objective and as Day 2 comes to a close and

2760.text:
even after additional reinforcements to the
82nd, no effort was being made to correct

2765.text:
this issue. The Germans at Nijmegen now blocked
the road to Arnhem. Think about it: If the

2770.text:
Allies don’t take Nijmegen Bridge soon,
1st Airborne would be isolated and potentially

2776.text:
crushed. Without Nijmegen, there could be
no Arnhem, and the whole Operation, would

2781.text:
be doomed.
If the 82nd had taken Nijmegen and the bridge

2784.text:
there rather than concentrating on taking
the Groesbeek Heights, how would things have

2787.text:
played out? Would it have been better or worse
than the situation we have now? I’d love

2792.text:
to hear your thoughts in the comments below.
Thanks for watching, thanks for subscribing,

2800.text:
bye for now.If everything goes to plan, youll
be relieved in two days. If not two, then

2806.text:
three days. Well, this was the day that British
tanks were meant to be rolling over Arnhem

2811.text:
bridge. And when we left yesterday, almost
everything seemed to be going great for Operation

2817.text:
Market Garden. Every bridge along the route
except one was in Allied hands, and although

2822.text:
the British tanks were still fifty miles to
the south at Son, by the morning of Day 3

2826.text:
the bailey bridge was finished. The road ahead
looked clear. The question is, would they

2839.text:
Yesterday we saw stalled attempts made by
1st Airborne to get to Frosts troops at the

2843.text:
bridge, whilst Frost himself and 2nd Battalion
continued to hold on. Ammunition and food

2849.text:
supplies were running low, so relief was desperately
needed now. The 82nd had destroyed the German

2855.text:
attack from the Reichswald, for only a handful
of losses, but only made token attempts to

2860.text:
take the Nijmegen bridge. Nijmegen was now
a German fortress. The 101st continued to

2864.text:
fight on all fronts, especially near Best,
whilst building a bailey bridge at Son, since

2869.text:
XXX Corps had finally arrived.
The 19th of September was a Tuesday. Its Day

2874.text:
3 of Operation Market Garden. The good news
was that XXX Corps and the 101st had finished

2881.text:
constructing the bailey bridge at Son and
were able to advance. Up to this point, XXX

2885.text:
Corps had gone 18 miles from their initial
starting positions. This may seem slow, and

2890.text:
it was, but they were about to make up for
it. The tanks reached Veghel by half 7 in

2896.text:
the morning, and by half eight, theyd covered
another 14 miles, reaching the 82nd at Grave.

2901.text:
In two hours, theyd advanced further than
theyd gone in the previous two days, around

2906.text:
24 miles. 42 hours after starting the Operation
they were now at Nijmegen and only about 8

2912.text:
miles from the British at Arnhem. There was
a good chance that theyd reach the British

2916.text:
in time. They still had an entire day left
to go the final 8 miles to Arnhem. 8 miles.

2922.text:
Except that the 82nd Airborne still hadnt
taken Nijmegen bridge… the only bridge not

2927.text:
taken intact or not on the first day, and
hadnt been in Allied hands at all. Nijmegen

2933.text:
bridge was now guarded by a lot of SS infantry,
supported by self...propelled guns, 88mm guns,

2936.text:
and artillery, and theyd had plenty of time,
unopposed by the 82nd, to fortify Nijmegen

2942.text:
city.
For the past two days, most of the 82nd Airborne

2947.text:
had sat on the Groesbeek Heights. There had
been no attacks on Groesbeek on the first

2951.text:
day. On the second day, a paper German division
had been repulsed without too much trouble.

2956.text:
And the Germans didnt mount any serious attacks
on the Heights the entire third day either.

2960.text:
The American units dug in at Groesbeek along
with Gavin and Browning had no impact on what

2966.text:
was now becoming a hard fought house...to...house
brawl for the city of Nijmegen and the southern

2972.text:
end of the Nijmegen bridge. As British tanks
and infantry moved towards Hunner park, they

2976.text:
came into the sights of the German 88mm guns.
Several tanks brewed up and the fighting began,

2982.text:
and would rage on for hours, with little ground
gained this day. Nijmegen was still in German

2989.text:
hands.
The Germans had two Kampfgruppen in the city

2992.text:
under the overall control of Kampfgruppe Reinhold
which was located at Lent, just north of Nijmegen.

2998.text:
One, Kampfgruppe Euling, held Hunner Park
and the Nijmegen Road Bridge, and the other,

3004.text:
Kampfgruppe Henke, guarded the Nijmegen Rail
Bridge. Euling only had around 100 men at

3009.text:
his disposal backed by four assault guns.
But they were veteran SS soldiers, supported

3014.text:
by a much larger contingent of artillery than
normal. SS...Lieutenant...Colonel Zonnenstahl

3020.text:
had four oversized batteries at his disposal.
Coupled with a unique way of delivering that

3026.text:
artillery… by putting boxes on a map and
naming or numbering them so it was easier

3031.text:
for forces on the ground to call for artillery
support… Zonnenstahl was able to bring down

3036.text:
copious amounts of fire to stall Allied assaults.
Harmel attributed the successful defence of

3042.text:
Nijmegen to this artillery support, which
allowed, over the course of the battle, the

3046.text:
small force of SS troops to maintain their
positions against a much larger attacking

3050.text:
force. Nijmegen wouldnt fall into Allied hands
this day.

3054.text:
But its ok, Frost was holding the bridge at
Arnhem. Just. There were now two German Kampfgruppen

3061.text:
surrounding him and they attacked on all sides.
Kampfgruppe Brinkmann continued to attack

3065.text:
from the East and Kampfgruppe Knaust, a heavier
battlegroup, now attacked from the North.

3070.text:
At the beginning of the day, 2 Paras perimeter
still consisted of 10 out of the original

3075.text:
18 houses theyd occupied on Day 1. But now,
the Germans were receiving a steady stream

3080.text:
of reinforcements. 88mm guns were brought
up to pound the buildings, and two Tiger tanks

3085.text:
managed to get through the wreck of vehicles
on the bridge and cross from the southern

3089.text:
side of the Rhine. Artillery fire from across
the river, including Nebelwerfers, hammered

3095.text:
the British positions. The battle was now
fully in the Germans favour as more assault

3099.text:
guns and Mark III and Mark IV tanks rolled
from the East. 2 Para was being blasted out

3104.text:
from its positions, one strong point at a
time. But the Germans didnt have it all their

3108.text:
own way. Rubble blocked the streets, making
it difficult for tanks to move up, and a few

3112.text:
vehicles and tanks were knocked out in the
fighting. The Paras were down to scraps of

3116.text:
ammunition, yet they continued to resist.
They did get some artillery support from 1st

3121.text:
Airborne, which did result in the Germans
turning their guns on the church spires thinking

3125.text:
artillery spotters were in them, but this
wasnt the case. According to Urquhart, [Frost

3129.text:
and Gough discussed the likelihood of Gough
and his Recce boys scalding across the Bridge

3134.text:
at last light to try and force a link with
XXX Corps.] You know its desperate when the

3138.text:
forces in need of relief are actually considering
aiding the relieving forces. The idea was

3143.text:
dropped, but the resistance continued, despite
the fact that Frost had to order his men to

3147.text:
stop sniping the Germans to conserve the little
ammunition they had left. The British could

3151.text:
now found it difficult move between the buildings
as German machine guns would open up in the

3155.text:
spaces between them. German infantry had to
assault the British houses and literally drag

3159.text:
the Paras out of their positions. It seemed
a hopeless situation for the British, but

3163.text:
they fought on, hoping that reinforcements
would come from either 1st Airborne, or from

3168.text:
the south.
Its worth noting that as long as 2nd Battalion

3171.text:
continued to hold out in Arnhem, the Germans
would have a difficult time reinforcing the

3175.text:
10th SS Panzer Division at Nijmegen. The Germans
were relying on the Pannerden Canal to get

3181.text:
their troops across the Rhine, but this was
slow. What this meant was that the Germans

3184.text:
at Nijmegen would receive no reinforcements
until 2nd Battalion were defeated, and 2nd

3191.text:
Battalion wouldnt receive reinforcements until
the Germans at Nijmegen were defeated too.

3196.text:
Effectively, there were two sieges going on
at the same time, and whichever cracked first

3200.text:
would decide the fate of the entire battle.
If German resistance collapsed at Nijmegen,

3205.text:
the British would get to Frost and be over
the Rhine. If Frost is defeated, German reinforcements

3211.text:
would stream into Nijmegen and 1st Airborne
would be doomed. There was still a chance

3216.text:
for both sides to claim victory.
But the difference between the Germans at

3220.text:
Nijmegen and Frost at Arnhem was was 2nd Battalion
was potentially about to get reinforced from

3225.text:
the West. 1st, 3rd, 4th and 11th Battalions,
supported by the South Staffords and elements

3231.text:
of 2nd Battalion who hadnt made it to the
bridge now attempted to break through to Frost.

3236.text:
Dobies 1st Battalion and half the South Staffords
went forwards first, supported by 3rd Battalion

3241.text:
who went in beside them. They cleared a few
light defenses where the Germans had had their

3246.text:
main line the day before. But then everything
went wrong. The Germans of Kampfgruppe Spindler

3251.text:
had pulled back slightly from the previous
days positions ... which did have the benefit

3256.text:
of allowing Urquhart to escape his prison
and make his way back to Divisional HQ ... but

3261.text:
it also meant the Germans now outflanked the
British on all sides. And this wasnt eyes

3267.text:
and ears battalions, this was the 9th SS Panzer
Division, armed with tanks, artillery and

3272.text:
self...propelled guns. Some occupied the route
ahead, others occupied the ridge to the north,

3277.text:
and more were positioned across the river
in the brickworks to the south. The lightly

3282.text:
armed British paratroopers, backed up by little
artillery, no air support or tanks and exhausted

3288.text:
on their third day of fighting, were hopelessly
caught in a crossfire. The 1st and 3rd Battalion

3293.text:
were pinned down by German fire and by 06:30,
after only two hours, the attack was over.

3297.text:
Those that survived were either wounded or
ran out of ammunition and were forced to surrender

3301.text:
in the next hour or so. The 140 men of 3rd
Battalion had been more or less wiped out.

3306.text:
1st Battalion and the first half of the South
Staffords suffered much the same fate.

3311.text:
The second half of the South Staffords now
went in, but found themselves facing German

3315.text:
tanks and self propelled guns near the museum.
Pinned down and with no anti...tank guns,

3320.text:
they had to rely on PIATs to try take out
the tanks, but by 11:30 theyd also run out

3325.text:
of PIAT anti...tank rounds. The Germans now
counter...attacked and overwhelmed the South

3329.text:
Staffords, who were forced to pull back through
11th Battalions positions.

3333.text:
11th Battalion, commanded by Lea, had been
ordered by Urquhart to wait. He wasnt happy

3338.text:
that attacks were going in piecemeal. As the
South Staffords fell back, 11th Battalion

3343.text:
was ordered to take the high ground north
of the railway line, hopefully so they could

3347.text:
mount a fresh attack later. But this took
time to prepare, and as they were setting

3351.text:
up, the Germans attacked. Mortars rained down
on them and tanks appeared. The 11th was in

3356.text:
the open preparing to advance. Caught off
guard by the Germans and in a hopeless situation,

3362.text:
the Battalion basically evaporated. Lea was
taken prisoner and maybe 150 men got away,

3366.text:
the rest were either killed or taken prisoner.
The last attempt to break through to Frost

3372.text:
at the bridge had failed with huge losses
to the British. 1st Brigade had been torn

3377.text:
to pieces and now, in the early afternoon,
the situation at Divisional HQ in Oosterbeek

3382.text:
looked bleak. The Germans were attacking into
Oosterbeek from the East and the landing zones

3386.text:
could no longer be held. This was the day
that the first of the RAF resupply drops fell

3391.text:
into enemy hands. 1st Airborne did receive
some reinforcements from a Polish Glider unit

3396.text:
landing at Landing Zone L. Unfortunately,
this went disastrously wrong for the Polish

3403.text:
as they landed on top of 10 Para Battalion
as they retreated south near Wolfheze. The

3408.text:
Polish were quite...literally shot out of
the sky and this didnt help 10 Paras retreat.

3412.text:
Chaos and confusion reigned, and Krafft was
able to push the British 10th and 156 Battalions

3418.text:
(both now down to around 250 men each) and
the surviving Poles beyond the railway line.

3423.text:
Urquhart desperately tried to organise a defence
as the light faded. He would later refer to

3429.text:
the 19th as a dark and fateful day. At Arnhem,
everything was going wrong.

3434.text:
Remember that bailey bridge at Son? You know,
the one built overnight? It had been incredibly

3439.text:
important in the days events, allowing British
tanks to roll on to Nijmegen. At 17:15 as

3445.text:
the American paratroopers sat in their positions
in and around Son watching British trucks

3449.text:
drive across the bridge... the Son church
tower exploded. Falling debris startled the

3454.text:
Americans as more explosions erupted from
the schoolhouse. General Taylor came out the

3459.text:
schoolhouse to see enemy infantry and Panther
tanks approaching from the south. Panzer Brigade

3465.text:
107 had arrived.
General Student had brought Panzer Brigade

3468.text:
107 up from Helmond and it was now just yards
from the newly built bailey bridge at Son.

3473.text:
A British truck was hit as it crossed the
bridge. It exploded and sent flames over the

3479.text:
span and into the canal. The Americans reacted
to the attack as best they could and even

3483.text:
managed to destroy two Panthers. One was knocked
out in sight of the bailey bridge as you can

3488.text:
see here. Fighting continued as darkness fell,
and only after the attack bogged down did

3492.text:
Panzer Brigade 107 withdraw. Two tanks had
been knocked out, but they had almost succeeded

3497.text:
in severing the supply line to the rest of
XXX Corps… and they werent defeated yet.

3501.text:
If we compare the situation at the beginning
of day 3 to the end of day 3, things had changed.

3507.text:
XXX Corps wasnt at Arnhem as expected, instead
they were fighting a house...to...house battle

3514.text:
for the city and bridge at Nijmegen. The 101st
at Son had built a bailey bridge in the morning

3517.text:
and only just managed to prevent it from falling
into German hands in the evening. And the

3521.text:
last attempt to get to Frost had failed. Now
the British around Oosterbeek were in a desperate

3526.text:
state as the Germans closed in on all sides.
Frost still clung onto Arnhem bridge though.

3532.text:
There was still a chance of victory... for
both sides. Everything was now at stake. Who

3537.text:
would fall first, the British at Arnhem or
the Germans at Nijmegen? Tomorrow would be

3542.text:
the last chance to get to Frost at Arnhem,
and it would require a lot more fight and

3547.text:
a daring feat of bravery from the soldiers
of the 82nd Airborne.

3552.text:
The 19th was truly a dark and fateful day.
A turning point. But do you think victory

3557.text:
could still have been achieved at this point?
Or was it already too late? And guys, if you

3561.text:
have any questions about this battle, comment
below and Ill get back to you as soon as I

3567.text:
can. Thanks for watching, thanks for subscribing,
bye for now.The Mad Colonel. That’s what

3574.text:
the Germans nicknamed John Frost who still
clung on to a handful of buildings at Arnhem

3580.text:
bridge. Frost’s men fought desperately with
their ammunition running out and the houses

3584.text:
collapsing and burning around them. Where
was XXX Corps? Where were the tanks? They

3589.text:
were 8 miles to the south fighting against
the 10th SS Panzer Division, who were clinging

3595.text:
on to the bridge at Nijmegen. Both Frost and
10th SS Panzer would fight two mirrored last

3601.text:
stands as the outcome of Operation Market
Garden hung in the balance. Who would fall

3613.text:
Yesterday was truly a dark and fateful day.
The British forces trying to get to Frost’s

3617.text:
men at Arnhem were almost wiped out having
been caught in a crossfire. The rest of 1st

3623.text:
Airborne were pushed off their landing zones
as General Urquhart, now back in charge of

3627.text:
the Division, tried to form a coherent defence.
XXX Corps had reached Nijmegen making up for

3633.text:
lost time, but were stopped as the 82nd had
failed to take Nijmegen bridge. The Germans

3638.text:
at Nijmegen were now under siege, but held
on, despite Allied attempts to break through.

3643.text:
The 101st had helped build a bailey bridge
at Son in the morning but fought to hold it

3647.text:
in the evening against Panther tanks of Panzer
Brigade 107.

3651.text:
It was now the 20th of September, a Wednesday.
Day 4 of Operation Market Garden. The tanks

3656.text:
should have reached Arnhem yesterday, but
they hadn’t. XXX Corps was still 8 miles

3662.text:
from Arnhem, and Nijmegen bridge was still
in German hands. But if they could break through

3666.text:
now, there was a chance of victory, even at
this late stage. 10th SS Panzer Division held

3672.text:
onto Nijmegen and the bridge with perhaps
500 men, backed by assault guns, 88mm guns,

3679.text:
mortars and artillery. When the British set
up for an attack, artillery rained down on

3683.text:
them and stopped them in their tracks, just
like the day before. Attempt after attempt

3688.text:
was made to smash the German defenders, but
Kampfgruppe Henke and Euling, under the command

3693.text:
of Kampfgruppe Reinhold, fought them off.
The stiffness of the German defence in Nijmegen

3698.text:
throughout the day didn’t seem to be weakening.
So the Allies decided that only desperate

3703.text:
action would save the day. At 15:00 in the
afternoon, Shermans blasted the opposite side

3708.text:
of the Waal as Major Cook’s 3rd Battalion
paddled in boats across the river. This was

3713.text:
perhaps one of the most heroic and daring
acts in World War 2, as American paratroopers

3719.text:
stormed across a river in boats, assaulted
a river bank like marines… which they weren’t

3725.text:
trained for… to take the Nijmegen bridge
from the other side. Unbelievably, under a

3729.text:
hail of rifle, machine gun and mortar fire,
half the boats made it to the North bank.

3735.text:
As the boats turned back to pick up the next
wave of troops, the American paratroopers

3740.text:
overwhelmed the old men and young boys who’d
been killing them moments before. This was

3744.text:
a decisive tactical victory for the Allies
which unhinged the German defence completely.

3750.text:
The Germans had nothing left. There were so
few units to form a defensive line that the

3755.text:
Americans, supported by British sappers, were
able to secure their beachhead and press on

3760.text:
towards the northern end of Nijmegen bridge.
Yes, you don’t hear that often, but the

3765.text:
American paratroopers were accompanied by
British sappers… the crossing was a joint

3770.text:
effort. They managed to get to the Northern
end of the Nijmegen Bridge, and as they did,

3773.text:
four sherman tanks from the British Grenadier
Guards attacked from the south. The tanks

3778.text:
moved across the span of the bridge, killing
the Germans in the girders. Just to point

3781.text:
out another myth of this battle, the Germans
in the girders were most likely engineers,

3786.text:
not snipers as often described. They were
perhaps trying to rig the bridge to blow,

3790.text:
but nobody’s quite sure, but after the war,
Harmel was convinced there weren’t snipers

3795.text:
on the bridge. Either way, it was at this
point that SS Colonel Harmel decided to blow

3800.text:
the road bridge. His orders from Field Marshal
Model were to keep the Road bridge intact,

3805.text:
so Germany could launch counter.attacks in
the future. This was an unrealistic eventuality

3810.text:
since Germany had little offensive capability
left, and Harmel understood that if he blew

3815.text:
the bridge now, it would prevent the Allies
from getting to Arnhem. As the British Sherman

3820.text:
tanks crossed the bridge, he ordered the bridge
be blown, but by some miracle, the explosives

3825.text:
failed to go off.
Lucky though the British were that the bridge

3828.text:
was now in their hands, they were unable to
advance. The four tanks they had on the other

3833.text:
side of the Waal were alone. The few American
paratroopers they had with them weren’t

3838.text:
willing or able to advance with them. It’s
often been said that an American paratrooper

3842.text:
became angry at the British tankers for not
advancing with them to Arnhem. This is fiction.

3848.text:
Another myth of the battle made up after the
event. In fact, the American paratroopers

3852.text:
may have even left the tanks at the bridge
to go fight Germans elsewhere. What is certain,

3857.text:
is that the handful of American paratroopers
who’d linked up with the tanks were too

3862.text:
few in number to go on and in any event were
in no position to take orders from the British.

3868.text:
Their orders were to hold the other side of
the bridge and it was down to the British

3873.text:
to advance. Unfortunately without infantry
support, the British tanks would be unable

3878.text:
to advance. So where were the British infantry?
XXX Corps has often been accused of being

3882.text:
too slow after the capture of Nijmegen bridge.
But the reality was that the British infantry

3887.text:
and tanks were still fighting against the
Germans who held on at Nijmegen. They couldn’t

3893.text:
just leave a good portion of 10th SS Panzer
Division there sitting in their rear, they

3898.text:
had to fight on. Some of the German defenders,
seeing the successful amphibious assault,

3902.text:
decided to flee across the railway bridge,
with around 250 dying on the bridge itself.

3907.text:
The Germans lost control of the Nijmegen railway
bridge but fighting continued in the city.

3912.text:
Artillery fire rained down on the British,
preventing them from overwhelming the last

3915.text:
pockets of resistance. Holding on for a few
more hours, the Germans finally realised their

3921.text:
position was hopeless. Some once again tried
to flee across the bridges, now in enemy hands.

3926.text:
Others, such as the survivors of Kampfgruppe
Euling, who’d held onto Hunner park, managed

3931.text:
to slip under the Nijmegen road bridge and
escape to the east. The British wouldn’t

3936.text:
clear the last elements of resistance from
Nijmegen until the early hours of the next

3939.text:
day. It wasn’t until Nijmegen was secure
that the British infantry and the rest of

3944.text:
XXX Corps could have continued their advance
to Arnhem.

3947.text:
So why was it that at the time, and after
the war, XXX Corps was accused of being so

3951.text:
slow? Why were they accused of drinking tea
on the Northern end of Nijmegen Bridge whilst

3956.text:
their comrades at Arnhem were left to bleed?
We’ll come back to that question in the

3961.text:
last episode of this series, but I’d love
to hear your opinions in the comments below.

3965.text:
As the fighting came to ahead in Nijmegen,
things further to the south weren’t easy

3969.text:
either. As the morning mist cleared at Son,
the Americans guarding the bailey bridge that

3974.text:
had been built on the previous night could
be forgiven for thinking they’d done their

3978.text:
part. The day before, they’d stopped a German
counter-attack which had nearly got to the

3982.text:
bridge, and could be satisfied that they’d
