completely secured the line. They were wrong.

3987.text:
Panzer Brigade 107 achieved complete surprise
by attacking the exact same way they’d done

3992.text:
the day before. You see, the Germans never
attacked in the same place twice. It just

3997.text:
wasn’t done. In theory, if you attacked
the same place twice, the enemy will be prepared.

4002.text:
That was why the Germans never did it, but
that’s exactly why they did it this day,

4007.text:
to throw the Americans off guard. And they
did. It wasn’t long before they dominated

4010.text:
the bailey bridge with fire once more. However,
in the nick of time, 10 British tanks appeared

4015.text:
and managed to destroy four more German tanks
and turn the tide of the battle in their favour.

4021.text:
Unable to take the bridge, Panzer Brigade
107 withdrew. It had once again been close

4026.text:
to cutting the Allied corridor, but this wasn’t
the only attack on the corridor this day.

4030.text:
406th Division which had attacked out of the
Reichswald forest near Groesbeek two days

4035.text:
ago was finally reinforced. Fallschirmjaeger,
German paratroopers, perhaps a few hundred

4040.text:
strong, joined the already weak 406th Division
and now formed three Kampfgruppen. Kampfgruppe

4047.text:
Becker with perhaps 800 men would strike Groesbeek
on the Northern end of the battlefield and

4052.text:
aim to take the Maas-Waal canal. Kampfgruppe
Greschick with maybe 500 men, attacked Groesbeek’s

4058.text:
center. And Kampfgruppe Hermann was positioned
in the south and would hope to strike through

4062.text:
Mook and cut off the bridges on the Maas-Waal
canal.

4065.text:
Starting in the morning, by 11:00 the battle
raged for the Groesbeek Heights. Beek, Wyler,

4070.text:
and Mook fell quickly, and Kampfgruppe Greschick’s
unit managed to take some of the outskirts

4076.text:
of Groesbeek itself. But an American counterattack
in the afternoon, supported by British tanks

4080.text:
forced the Germans back from Mook and Groesbeek,
and the attack in the north was halted. This

4085.text:
was the first serious attack on the Groesbeek
Heights so far. It was four days after the

4090.text:
Operation had begun, and well after XXX Corps
had arrived, but at least the 82nd had four

4096.text:
days to prepare themselves for the fight.
It was only now, at the extreme north of the

4100.text:
battlefield, that Urquhart came to the conclusion
that he had to abandon the idea of relieving

4106.text:
Frost at the Bridge. To use his own words…
[...with the weak force now left, I could

4110.text:
no more hope to reach Frost than reach Berlin.]
Later in the same day he finally made contact

4115.text:
with Frost over the radio. Urquhart told him
he wasn’t certain [if it was a case of me

4120.text:
coming for them or they coming for us.] And
so with the British 1st Airborne Division

4124.text:
abandoning all hope of getting the Frost’s
beleaguered troops at Arnhem bridge, they

4128.text:
instead had to look to their own defence.
The previous days action had seen their attacking

4133.text:
force in Arnhem decimated by the Germans.
1st Parachute Brigade no longer existed and

4138.text:
the remnants of several Battalions fell back
into Oosterbeek. The landing zones were overrun

4143.text:
and supplies were dropping to the Germans
rather than to themselves, and German tanks

4148.text:
were pressing upon their lines. Urquhart decided
the remaining units should fall back to positions

4152.text:
immediately around Oosterbeek. He had to form
a defense quickly before the remainder of

4157.text:
the Division was wiped out.
Throughout the day, Urquhart tried to salvage

4161.text:
what was left of the original Market Garden
plan. If he could no longer get to Arnhem

4166.text:
Bridge, he would hold Oosterbeek and hopefully
keep a crossing point open for XXX Corps.

4172.text:
It was a desperate plan, but it might just
work. The casualty list for 1st Airborne was

4178.text:
staggering. It was no longer a division but
a few stragglers and small groups falling

4183.text:
back to Oosterbeek. But if they could hold
on to Oosterbeek, and the Heveadorp Ferry,

4187.text:
a bailey bridge could be set up across the
Rhine and victory could still be clawed from

4192.text:
the jaws of defeat. With that in mind, he
told Corps HQ to change the Polish drop zone

4197.text:
to Driel, near to the southern end of the
ferry. If the Polish held the southern end

4201.text:
of the river, and the rest of 1st Airborne
held the northern end, there was a chance

4206.text:
XXX Corps could still cross the Rhine. It
was a desperate plan, but a plan it was.

4211.text:
To the East, Kampfgruppe Spindler crossed
the railway lines and reached the east of

4216.text:
Oosterbeek. To the west, von Tettau’s Kampfgruppe
pushed the British back from their drop zones

4220.text:
and took Wolfheze. 4th Brigade of the British
paras did manage to stall the attacks for

4225.text:
a time, mauling part of Krafft’s attack,
and even counter attacked, despite their orders

4229.text:
saying to retreat. Hackett fought alongside
his men, brandishing a German gun, trying

4234.text:
desperately to get him men back towards Oosterbeek.
During the confused fighting in the woods,

4239.text:
there was no real front line as such, just
groups of units moving around, ambushing and

4243.text:
sniping at each other. Towards the evening,
Hackett’s remnants fell back to Oosterbeek

4248.text:
and recognisable lines were finally formed.
Both sides took sizable losses in the day’s

4252.text:
fighting, and this is perhaps the reason why
von Tettau decided not to deliver a coup de

4258.text:
grace and destroy the British pocket completely
now as they retreated, which some historians

4262.text:
think may have been possible. Either way,
by the evening of the 20th, the British pocket

4267.text:
was formed at Oosterbeek, and the fluid movement
of the past few days ended. The siege had

4273.text:
begun.
This was 1st Airborne’s disposition at the

4276.text:
end of the Day, 20th September 1944. 10th
and 156 Battalions, who had fought their way

4282.text:
back into Oosterbeek from the West during
the day were now guarding the Eastern side

4287.text:
of Oosterbeek that evening. This was because
1st, 3rd and 11th Battalions were so badly

4291.text:
mauled, they were merely scraps of the units
they once were. Lieutenant-Colonel Thompson

4295.text:
took command of this force, which was nicknamed
the Thompson Force. But Thompson was later

4300.text:
wounded and from the 21st onwards (tomorrow),
Major Lonsdale took command of this battlegroup,

4307.text:
which for the sake of simplicity we will now
refer to as the Lonsdale Force. 21st Independent

4310.text:
Parachute Company, together with the 7th Battalion
King’s Own Scottish Borderers, held the

4315.text:
Northern end of Oosterbeek around Hotel Dreyeroord,
a building soon nicknamed as the White House.

4322.text:
9th Airborne Field Company and 1st Border
held the Western side of Oosterbeek. Inside

4326.text:
this ring were Glider pilots who fought alongside
the troops, the Royal Artillery, which was

4331.text:
located towards the southern end of the pocket,
and Divisional Headquarters which was located

4336.text:
at the Hartenstein Hotel.
Little more than three thousand six hundred

4340.text:
men remained of 1st Airborne Division, and
supplies of all kinds were running low. But

4345.text:
Urquhart had successfully created a defence
around Oosterbeek, even though it wasn’t

4349.text:
a complete ring and was more groups of soldiers
dug in at strong points.

4353.text:
Frost’s position was now perilous. Movement
was almost impossible and the few buildings

4357.text:
they had left on the western side of the Arnhem
bridge ramp were surrounded. Truces allowed

4361.text:
the defenders to evacuate their wounded, which
included their leader, Frost himself. They’d

4367.text:
run out of everything, food, water and ammunition.
In fact, the Germans were also low on ammunition,

4372.text:
with many of them resorting to using captured
British rifles and Sten guns, as their own

4376.text:
logistics struggled to keep up. The shortcomings
of German supply were alleviated by the Allied

4381.text:
resupply drops which, as we mentioned, were
falling into German hands. The Germans blasted

4386.text:
the British houses at the Bridge at point
blank range. They had Tiger tanks at hand,

4391.text:
including the latest shipment of Konigstiger,
or King Tiger tanks. The lightly armed paratroopers

4396.text:
had no effective countermeasures against these
heavy German tanks. Luckily, rubble prevented

4402.text:
German vehicles from maneuvering with ease.
But this only slowed the inevitable. There

4406.text:
were only a few buildings left now, and many
of them were on fire.

4410.text:
So at 19:10, the British and Americans took
the Nijmegen bridge. But it would take all

4416.text:
night to clear Nijmegen so that they could
continue their northern attack. As this day

4420.text:
comes to an end, we see the end of two sieges.
Arnhem bridge, and Nijmegen. Elements of 2

4425.text:
Para continued to hold, just, but they had
no influence now over the bridge itself. For

4429.text:
both sides it was now a race to engage each
other in the area between Nijmegen and Arnhem.

4434.text:
An area known as The Island. We’ll find
out how that race goes tomorrow.

4437.text:
If you could rate the video and let me know
how I’m doing, that would be great! Otherwise,

4441.text:
thanks for watching, thanks for subscribing,
bye for now.Total Victory was now out of the

4453.text:
question. But the tanks had to get to Oosterbeek
where 1st Airborne were besieged in a pocket

4458.text:
- what the Germans called the “Hexenkessel”
- or witches cauldron. Over the next two days,

4464.text:
the British race north from Nijmegen to get
to the paratroopers and the Germans race south

4469.text:
from Arnhem to stop them. If the British get
to Oosterbeek, and if they can get reinforcements

4474.text:
across the river, there was still a chance
they could claw their way to victory.

4480.text:
Intro graphic
Last time, we saw Frost’s perimeter shrink

4486.text:
to a few houses, while Frost himself is taken
prisoner. 1st Airborne was forced back into

4492.text:
Oosterbeek to form some sort of defence. 3rd
Battalion of the 504th heroically crossed

4496.text:
the Waal and took the north side of Nijmegen
bridge as tanks of XXX Corps crossed the span.

4502.text:
German resistance continued in Nijmegen though
for several more hours, preventing the British

4507.text:
from striking north. And the 101st held against
a second surprise attack from Panzer Brigade

4513.text:
107.
In this episode I’m going to cover two days,

4516.text:
the 21st of September and the 22nd. Let’s
start with the 21st, a Thursday, Day 5 of

4523.text:
Operation Market Garden. At Arnhem bridge,
the last gasps of 2nd Battalion could be heard

4528.text:
as they held on in the hope of relief… but
it was all in vein. Organised British resistance

4533.text:
collapsed sometime in the morning of the 21st
of September. Although it’s worth mentioning

4538.text:
that some lone British paratroopers continued
to fight on until the 23rd. Arnhem was now

4543.text:
totally within German hands. The last radio
message from the bridge, picked up by Germans

4549.text:
and not by any Allied unit, read [Out of Ammunition.
God Save the King.] Frost’s men were finally

4556.text:
overwhelmed at Arnhem and the Germans had
access to Arnhem bridge and the road south.

4561.text:
With the loss of Arnhem Bridge, total victory
for the Allies was now impossible, but they

4566.text:
still had a chance to get to the British at
Oosterbeek and get a bridge across the Rhine.

4571.text:
At least, that is what Urquhart hoped.
Around 3,600 paratroopers held the newly formed

4576.text:
perimeter at Oosterbeek. The important point
to note at this time is that the Heveadorp

4581.text:
ferry area was still within British hands.
Unfortunately, the ferry itself had been sunk

4586.text:
the day before, just in case it fell into
German hands, but the area was the best place

4590.text:
near Oosterbeek to maybe form a bailey bridge
since there were roads close to the river.

4595.text:
Holding onto this area was therefore the last
chance for victory. It fell to a handful of

4599.text:
men from 1st Border to keep Heveadorp in British
hands.

4603.text:
At around 08:00, the Germans attacked from
all sides of the Oosterbeek perimeter. They

4608.text:
used assault guns and tanks to support their
infantry assaults, but there was an unexpected

4613.text:
stiffness to the British defences. Unlike
in the previous days actions, the British

4618.text:
had a lot of troops in a very small mostly
wooded or urban area, and they were defending.

4624.text:
This gave them an advantage they hadn’t
had in the past. 9th SS, championed by units

4630.text:
like Kampfgruppe Spindler, attacked from the
east. German snipers did manage to infiltrate

4636.text:
the British positions, since there weren’t
enough British to form a solid defensive line.

4642.text:
These snipers took their toll, but the British
resisted strongly. They took out some of the

4645.text:
German tanks, or forced them back with heavy
AT fire. They even managed to capture a Sturmgeschütz

4652.text:
assault gun from the Germans, but couldn’t
figure out how to use it, so had to abandon

4658.text:
it. However, 10th Battalion were decimated
in the center during the day’s action with

4664.text:
only a handful of men able to fall back. Despite
this loss, the Germans maybe gained a couple

4669.text:
hundred meters of ground the entire day. In
the west, Von Tettau’s untrained troops

4673.text:
also made little progress against the tight
British defence, with British sniper fire

4677.text:
now taking a heavy toll on the Germans. However
the Heveadorp ferry area was captured by the

4682.text:
Germans after a heavy fight, and with it,
the last chance of Operation Market Garden

4687.text:
succeeding.
British supplies were once again dropping

4689.text:
behind enemy lines. The Paras set up all manner
of signals on the ground to try and sway the

4694.text:
RAF to drop supplies to them, but they failed.
The RAF were now suffering heavy losses, resupplying

4700.text:
their enemy, who were then using those supplies
to fight the Paras who the supplies were meant

4705.text:
to be for. But the good news for 1st Airborne
was that, today, contact was finally made

4709.text:
with XXX Corp. And XXX Corps had artillery,
which the belligerent paratroopers called

4714.text:
on to stall the Germans. Steel rain blunted
several German attacks, and the Germans thought

4718.text:
their artillery was firing short, so they
tried firing flares to stop their own artillery

4724.text:
firing. Nope, it was British artillery, and
this would be a big reason for why the British

4728.text:
would continue to hold out at Oosterbeek over
the next few days. Like at Nijmegen, artillery

4733.text:
was useful in preventing attacks from forming,
and when the British paras saw an attack forming,

4738.text:
they’d simply call in artillery to disrupt
the German attacks.

4742.text:
More good news for 1st Airborne came in the
afternoon. At 17:00 a new armada covered the

4747.text:
skies. The Polish Independent Parachute Brigade
descended from the heavens. Now, weather in

4753.text:
England had delayed the Poles from setting
off. They’d were originally meant to be

4757.text:
dropped two days earlier, on Day 3 of the
Operation, and they were supposed to drop

4761.text:
near Arnhem. But the situation had changed
dramatically since then, so Urquhart changed

4766.text:
the plan at the last minute to drop the Poles
north of Driel, which was south of the Rhine

4772.text:
and south of the Oosterbeek Cauldron. Their
task was to support 1st Airborne as best they

4776.text:
could, and if possible, get men and supplies
across the Rhine. It was also to guard the

4781.text:
approaches to the river so XXX Corps could
maybe attempt a crossing.

4786.text:
However, things went wrong for the Poles right
from the start. A portion of the Brigade didn’t

4791.text:
take off from England. And whilst the Allies
may have had air superiority over most of

4794.text:
Europe, they did not over this battlefield.
You see, in previous months, the RAF and US

4800.text:
Air Force had dominated the skies, disrupting
German movements and logistics, and bombed

4805.text:
German ground units at the request of Allied
units. But because the US Air Force feared

4809.text:
mixing fighters with transport planes, there
were little to no air support available for

4814.text:
the Allied units during Operation Market Garden.
As a result, the German Luftwaffe was able

4819.text:
to hunt down a portion of the American planes
taking the Poles to their destination. General

4823.text:
Urquhart was of the opinion after the war
that the lack of air support was a deciding

4828.text:
factor in this battle.
Once the Poles reached Driel and parachuted

4831.text:
to their destination, they realised two things.
One - only around a thousand men, perhaps

4837.text:
less, of their entire Brigade had made it.
And two - that the British at Oosterbeek had

4840.text:
lost the area around the Heveadorp Ferry.
This threw off the original plan to have the

4845.text:
Poles support XXX Corps in crossing the Rhine.
Their only hope now was to try and assist

4850.text:
1st Airborne as best they could, and maybe
get troops across the river to them.

4853.text:
The Germans were taken completely by surprise
by the Polish landing! They feared the worst

4858.text:
- that the Poles would get across the Rhine,
or perhaps even swing around their rear and

4863.text:
capture the southern end of the Arnhem bridge!
This would cut off 9th SS’s retreat as XXX

4869.text:
Corps would crush them from the front. This
was a fantasy because a thousand or so paratroopers

4873.text:
weren’t capable of doing that. But nonetheless,
the Germans reacted quickly, sending all available

4877.text:
reserves to form a blocking line or “Sperrverband”,
named after its commander, Harzer. Sperrverband

4884.text:
Harzer consisted of 5 Battalions, perhaps
as many as 2,400 men, and now blocked the

4889.text:
route to Arnhem. This force engaged the 1000
or so Poles in the Driel area as the Poles

4894.text:
formed an all round defense, waiting for XXX
Corps to link up with them.

4897.text:
The impact of the Polish drop is significant.
Whilst they couldn’t get across the Rhine,

4901.text:
because the Ferry was lost, they did draw
off all German reserves in the area. According

4905.text:
to Robert J. Kershaw in his book, ‘It Never
Snows In September’, the Germans had been

4910.text:
planning to destroy the British at Oosterbeek
in a planned attack on the 22nd. But now had

4915.text:
to take all their reserves to counter the
Polish drop. If this is true, the Polish saved

4920.text:
1st Airborne from complete annihilation.
The Polish drop would also give the Allies

4924.text:
a last chance to cross the Rhine. XXX Corps
sent reconnaissance units forwards into the

4928.text:
area known as “The Island”. In this area,
the main road was raised up above the surrounding

4933.text:
fields, themselves split, not by hedges, but
by ditches and streams. Basically, British

4938.text:
tanks advancing this way would be exposed
to anything the Germans could fire at them,

4942.text:
with little chance of retaliation. So, even
though XXX Corps resumed its attack towards

4946.text:
Arnhem at 13:30, it soon got bogged down in
the fighting. Five leading tanks were hit

4952.text:
and set on fire by Panther and 88mm guns and
the attack ground to a halt.

4956.text:
With the tanks unable to proceed, it was decided
that infantry should lead the attack. And

4962.text:
the 43rd Infantry Division was picked for
this role. Unfortunately, the 43rd Infantry

4966.text:
Division was stuck at Nijmegen, and the traffic
up the one road, now referred to by the Americans

4971.text:
as [Hell’s Highway] was awful. So the attack
was delayed. The Germans were also sending

4976.text:
a steady stream of reinforcements into the
Island area, meaning there was little chance

4981.text:
of reaching either 1st Airborne or the Poles
this day.

4984.text:
The 22nd of September was a Friday, and it
was now Day 6 of Operation Market Garden.

4989.text:
Like the day before, there was still hope
that XXX Corps could reach the paratroopers

4993.text:
at Oosterbeek and create some sort of victory.
That chance was lost today as Kampfgruppe

4997.text:
Walther launched a counterattack, not in the
north at the Island, but at Veghel against

5003.text:
the 101st. They aimed to cut the corridor,
as they had tried to do at Son a few days

5007.text:
earlier. Again it was the Panther tanks of
Panzer Brigade 107 that headed the attack.

5012.text:
This time though, it was supported by Grenadiers,
flak batteries, artillery, Fallschirmjaeger,

5016.text:
a Tank Destroyer Battalion, and more. They
would attack the right flank of the road - which

5021.text:
was now nicknamed ‘Hell’s Highway’ by
the Allies. On the left side of the road,

5025.text:
another formation - Kampfgruppe Huber - also
went in on the attack. This had infantry,

5029.text:
supported by artillery, AntiTank guns and
even four Jagdpanther tank destroyers. This

5034.text:
force would attack at Schijndel but aimed
at Veghel. Despite a shortage of artillery

5039.text:
shells, this was a concerted attack and proved
devastating for the 101st and the British

5043.text:
too.
Shortly after 09:00, the German attack went

5047.text:
in. Artillery pounded the American positions
and the tanks of Kampfgruppe Walther moved

5052.text:
off ahead of the other infantry units. Veghel
was reached at around 11:00 with Panther tanks

5055.text:
and Panzer Grenadiers cutting Hell’s Highway
to the north. They then turned south to Veghel

5060.text:
where a battle erupted with the American 501st
Regiment. On the other side of the road, Kampfgruppe

5064.text:
Huber got into the outskirts of Schijndel,
where they were able to fire at the Veghel

5068.text:
canal bridge. The 506th Regiment, supported
by British tanks, were able to push them back.

5073.text:
Equally, the 501st, supported by British tanks
and an unending artillery barrage, halted

5078.text:
Kampfgruppe Walther. The Germans found themselves
unable to continue the attack as night fell,

5084.text:
but they had cut the corridor, and this meant
that XXX Corps’ supplies and reinforcements

5088.text:
wouldn’t get through to the North.
And the British desperately needed infantry

5092.text:
reinforcements in the north. Some elements,
including tanks, of 43rd Division managed

5097.text:
to reach the Polish Independent Brigade at
Driel sometime in the evening. But the Island

5101.text:
still caused problems and an attack could
not be made successfully towards Arnhem. Worse,

5106.text:
tank units at Nijmegen that could be used
to advance north, were sent south to deal

5112.text:
with the Veghel cut. Clearly, the British
attack was losing steam.

5115.text:
Lieutenant Colonel Charles MacKenzie - the
staff officer who’d told Hicks he was in

5119.text:
charge of 1st Airborne when Urquhart was missing
- crossed the Rhine in a rowing boat and spoke

5126.text:
to Polish commander Sosabowski. He impressed
upon Sosabowski the desperate situation in

5130.text:
the Oosterbeek Cauldron, and said that even
a handful of reinforcements could make all

5134.text:
the difference. That night, 60 men from Sosabowski’s
Brigade got across the river and reinforced

5139.text:
the Oosterbeek perimeter.
But 60 Polish paratroopers weren’t enough

5143.text:
to change the course of the battle. Harzer
had decided that the British in the Oosterbeek

5147.text:
pocket would be pounded into submission by
mortars and Nebelwerfers, rather than all

5153.text:
out attacks. There were a few reasons behind
this change of tactics. One was that a good

5157.text:
portion of the German reinforcements had moved
south to block the Polish landing and the

5161.text:
British tanks. Essentially, the British pocket
at Oosterbeek was now merely a distraction

5166.text:
from the main event further south. Another
reason was that the Germans left at Oosterbeek

5171.text:
were mostly untrained conscripts, backed by
only a few veteran kampfgruppen. These troops

5177.text:
would not be capable of mounting the assaults
needed to root the British out of their strong

5183.text:
points. Attacks were still carried out, but
it wasn’t the all-out storming of positions

5187.text:
that would overwhelm the Paras from all sides
kind of attack the British were expecting.

5192.text:
As a result, the British pocket remained virtually
unchanged and the Paras continued to hold.

5196.text:
So, the battle had shifted in the last couple
of days. Frost’s men fought on until the

5200.text:
very end. The Poles had landed, causing the
Germans to move reinforcements south, perhaps

5204.text:
saving 1st Airborne from annihilation. XXX
Corps had problems linking up with the Poles,

5209.text:
especially since Hell’s Highway had been
cut near Veghel. And with the loss of the

5213.text:
Heveadorp Ferry, it now seemed unlikely that
the Allies could still achieve a victory.

5217.text:
If you were Urquhart, and you had the choice
of choosing the Polish landing zone, where

5221.text:
would you drop them? Would you choose Driel?
Would you land them south of Arnhem, or would

5226.text:
you land them somewhere on the North side
of the Rhine to support 1st Airborne? Let

5230.text:
me know in the comments below. Thanks for
watching, thanks for subscribing, bye for

5238.text:
now.Hold on. Hold on until the tanks relieve
you. Hold on without reinforcement or resupply.

5247.text:
Hold on until victory. Except there won’t
be a victory. This battle is lost. It was

5253.text:
lost days ago. You’re just holding on until
someone decides to get you out. Such was the

fate of the British Paras at Oosterbeek.
Info graphic

5267.text:
Last time we saw the Poles drop at Driel and

5271.text:
of Arnhem. The corridor was cut at Veghel

5276.text:
The Germans at Oosterbeek pounded the British
paras whilst the Red Devils held on inside

5281.text:
the Witches Cauldron.
This time, we’re going to cover the last

5283.text:
few days of Operation Market Garden, starting
from the 23rd of September and ending on the

5289.text:
26th.
You’ll be surprised to learn that the remaining

5291.text:
airborne reinforcements flew in on the 23rd
of September. Yes! 7 days after the beginning

5298.text:
of the Operation, the Poles received the rest
of their Brigade that hadn’t taken off two

5302.text:
days previously. The 101st and the 82nd also
received additional reinforcements, including

5308.text:
an entire regiment, the 325th Glider Infantry,
that landed at Nijmegen.

5313.text:
With additional reinforcements, the Allies
pushed Kampfgruppe Walther back towards Gemert

5318.text:
in the evening of the 23rd. Defeated it may
have been, but Kampfgruppe Walther had cut

5323.text:
Hell’s Highway for 36 hours. Unfortunately,
Walther was now in a poor position to attack

5327.text:
the corridor once more, since British VIII
Corps was now in Deurne. Over the next couple

5334.text:
of days, it would withdraw to Boxmeer and
would play no further part in the battle.

5339.text:
On the 24th however, Kampfgruppe Huber, on
the other side of Hell’s Highway, attacked

5343.text:
towards Veghel. This Kampfgruppe was weaker
than Walther, consisting of perhaps four Fallschirmjager

5350.text:
battalions backed up by Jagdpanther tank destroyers.
But the Germans had done their reconnaissance.

5356.text:
They’d found gaps in the American lines.
Striking into Eerde from Schijndel, the German

5361.text:
Jagdpanthers annihilated British tanks supported
by American paratroopers. Several Shermans

5365.text:
were taken out, and trucks burst into flames
on Hell’s Highway itself. Now, whilst the

5370.text:
Germans hadn’t got to the road, they had
prevented traffic from flowing north. Once

5375.text:
again the corridor was cut. Worse, another
force from Kampfgruppe Huber attacked towards

5379.text:
Koevering the next day. Ambushing vehicles
on the road, Fallschirmjager did enough damage

5383.text:
to cut the road again. Fifty vehicles were
destroyed and the road was blocked here until

5388.text:
the 26th - day 10 of Operation Market Garden
- and basically the end.

5392.text:
On the 24th, Day 8 of the Operation, a meeting
was held at Valburg between Horrocks, Browning,

5398.text:
Thomas and Sosabowski to decide what to do.
Sosabowski pointed out that sending reinforcements

5404.text:
into Oosterbeek was pointless unless a major
crossing could be made involving a lot more

5408.text:
troops. This though, was not possible. A major
crossing could not be mounted because XXX

5410.text:
Corps was stretched too thin and had logistical
troubles in the south. Instead, Horrocks decided

5414.text:
that small crossings would have to continue
for the time being. Interestingly, he told

5418.text:
Sosabowski that if he didn’t like the idea,
he would be relieved of his command. Yes,

5424.text:
Horrocks was under pressure, but it may seem
a little odd that Sosabowski was threatened

5428.text:
with resignation. I’ll go into more detail
as to why there was a distrust of the Polish

5433.text:
commander in the next, and final episode of
the series. But either way, on the night of

5438.text:
the 24th, more assault boats arrived and 300
men, mostly Poles got into Oosterbeek - a

5443.text:
lot were killed trying to make the crossing.
With the corridor cut further south, XXX Corps

5447.text:
struggled to press on towards Oosterbeek.
On the evening of the 23rd, 130th Brigade

5452.text:
finally reached the Poles at Driel, making
this the first substantial connection XXX

5456.text:
Corps had with the forces fighting on the
Rhine. They still fought the Germans at Elst

5460.text:
and Bemmel and would take Opheusden by the
26th.

5466.text:
Even with a 300 man reinforcement, and the
arrival (at last!) of Allied fighter bombers

5471.text:
from the 23rd onwards, the situation in Oosterbeek
during the last few days of the Operation

5476.text:
remained bleak. Despite being assaulted by
tanks, grenades, and a host of other weapons,

5480.text:
including flamethrowers - specially requested
by German commanders and ordered in by Model

5483.text:
himself - somehow 1st Airborne continued to
hold on. It was joked at the time that the

5488.text:
British used German weapons - since their
ammunition had run out - and the Germans used

5493.text:
British weapons, since their own logistics
were strained and they were getting resupplied

5499.text:
by the Allies via the drop zones. And the
Germans still didn’t have enough troops

5502.text:
to deliver a decisive blow on the Cauldron.
Worse, the troops that the Germans did have

5507.text:
were suffering high casualties as they tried
to storm each of the British strong points,

5512.text:
since the defence of Oosterbeek was now a
series of strong points rather than a continuous

5518.text:
line. German commanders were angry that their
troops were losing as many tanks as they were.

5523.text:
The reason for the losses was because the
German infantry weren’t trained and were

5527.text:
few in number, and because there was a shortage
of radios amongst the Germans. British AT

5532.text:
tank guns and infantry managed to knock out
numerous German vehicles, including Sturmgeschutz

5537.text:
Self-Propelled guns and even some Panther
tanks. Surprisingly, the German Konigstiger

5542.text:
- or King Tiger tanks - weren’t that effective
at Oosterbeek due to the narrow terrain which

5548.text:
took off their tracks and prevented their
turrets from turning. This was of little comfort

5552.text:
to the British, who didn’t realise that
the Germans were reorganising their lines.

5556.text:
The Germans pulled in all their veterans from
the various kampfgruppen that surrounded the

5561.text:
British pocket, and put them on the Eastern
side.

5564.text:
It was hoped that this reorganisation would
enable the Germans to pierce the British perimeter

5569.text:
and bring about the end of British resistance.
An attack was mounted in the afternoon of

5573.text:
the 25th, and actually penetrated the British
lines. Somehow the British managed to stop

5577.text:
the Germans, who’s attack lost momentum
quickly, due to fierce resistance and a huge

5582.text:
amount of British artillery. The British called
in artillery and (finally) airstrikes on the

5587.text:
Germans to stall the attacks, whilst the Germans
used Nebelwerfers - rocket artillery to pound

5592.text:
the British into submission. A lot of British
prisoners taken in these critical days were

5597.text:
shell shocked by these strikes. Water and
medical supplies were all but gone, and truces

5602.text:
had to be called to evacuate the wounded to
German hospitals in Arnhem. Thousands of British

5607.text:
troops would end up as prisoners of war for
this reason, perhaps as many as 6000 at the

5613.text:
end of the battle.
Having hung on for nine days, the Paras were

5616.text:
finished. On the evening of the 25th, a plan
to withdraw across the Rhine was put in place

5621.text:
and the paratroopers crossed the Rhine in
small boats throughout the night, under the

5625.text:
cover of artillery fire. By the early morning
of the 26th, the evacuation was over and the

5630.text:
survivors of 1st Airborne met at Driel. Just
1,741 of 1st Airborne had made it to Allied

5638.text:
lines. The rest of the 10,000 that had dropped
into the Arnhem area were either killed, wounded

5644.text:
and/or captured. In contrast, the Germans
had lost around 3,000 men in the Arnhem sector.

5649.text:
Another German attack went in on the 26th…
and found no resistance. The Germans were

5653.text:
surprised. All they found were dead bodies
and weapons. The British had gone! Yes, the

5659.text:
field hospitals were full, but it dawned on
them that the British had withdrawn overnight.

5664.text:
They had succeeded. They’d defeated the
British. They’d won.

5667.text:
And thus ended Operation Market Garden. It
was day 10 now after the battle had begun

5672.text:
and at best you could probably call it a draw,
but really it was a defeat for the Allies.

5677.text:
The British had failed to cross the Rhine,
their ultimate objective, and although the

5681.text:
Allied troops had fought heroically throughout
the battle, they’d tried to go a Bridge

5685.text:
Too Far. Total losses for both sides vary,
depending on which source you use. It’s

5690.text:
safe to assume that German losses were somewhere
around six to nine thousand men, although

5696.text:
the actual number may never be known. Allied
losses may be as high as 17,000, with around

5702.text:
half of them, over 8,000, being from 1st Airborne
alone.

5706.text:
But this series isn’t over yet. We have
one more main episode to go. And it’s a

5711.text:
biggy. The question we’re going to ask,
and I’ll ask you guys now is, who was to

5715.text:
blame for the failure of Operation Market
Garden? Comment below and let me know.

5719.text:
We’ve seen what happened. We’ve watched
the battle unfold. Now we get to decide who

5723.text:
should take the blame for this defeat. We
will find out next time. And there will also

5727.text:
in the main narrative so stay tuned. Thanks
for watching, thanks for subscribing, bye

5734.text:
for now.If you’ve watched all episodes in
this series so far, then you know what the

5740.text:
plan was. You’ve seen what happened. You
know the outcome. Now we have to ask the question

5746.text:
that has sparked controversy ever since: Who
was to blame for the failure of Operation

5758.text:
This was the biggest airborne operation of
all time and the last major defeat of the

5762.text:
British military. Historians have come up
with a host of reasons for the failure of

5766.text:
Market Garden and we’re going to delve into
them today. If you’ve watched from the beginning

5770.text:
of this series, you’ll have seen the battle
as it happened. But just so we’re up to

5775.text:
speed, let’s quickly recap.
The plan was to take all the bridges between

5778.text:
Eindhoven and Arnhem using paratroopers and
create a corridor for British tanks and infantry

5783.text:
to drive up and over, and off into the Netherlands.
We saw how the initial landings went well,

5787.text:
and we’ve seen how most of the bridges were
taken without much trouble. Only a small portion

5791.text:
of the British paras got to Arnhem bridge,
but they held until the fourth day of the

5796.text:
Operation. The Polish had dropped five days
later and fought well to try support the British

5801.text:
on the opposite side of the Rhine. Son bridge
had blown, but was rebuilt by the 101st and

5807.text:
by XXX Corps who made good their delay and
raced to Nijmegen. Here they fought a tough

5811.text:
battle for Nijmegen city and the bridge, which
as a result of the determined and heroic effort

5818.text:
from the soldiers of the American 82nd Airborne,
saw the capture of that bridge. Sadly, despite

5823.text:
the efforts of every Allied soldier up and
down the corridor, the Germans had delayed

5828.text:
them long enough to prevent them getting to
the final bridge. Arnhem bridge. As General

5834.text:
Browning had supposedly said before the battle,
it was “a bridge too far”. [Again, it’s

5838.text:
debated whether he actually said that or not,
but it serves it’s purpose.]

5839.text:
It may come as a shock then to hear that,
immediately after the battle, Sosabowski (commander

5843.text:
of the Polish paras) was relieved of command
and blamed for the failure of Operation Market

5848.text:
Garden. What? Why? This may seem a little
strange, and it was. Because of bad weather,

5852.text:
the Polish had landed five days after the
beginning of the Operation, and despite a

5857.text:
portion of their force jumping into the jaws
of the enemy, they’d fought hard to support

5862.text:
the British trapped at Oosterbeek. Why then,
was Sosabowski relieved? How could he be blamed

5867.text:
for the failure of Operation Market Garden?
The truth is that at the time, a scapegoat

5873.text:
was needed. And the Polish were an easy target.
Some have even suggested that the Poles were

5878.text:
only included in the battle just in case it
did go wrong. After the war, historians started

5883.text:
to look deeper into the reasons for the failure
of the Operation, and nobody now thinks the

5889.text:
Polish were to blame.
So, let’s look at three of the main arguments

5892.text:
for the failure of Operation Market Garden.
The first argument is that it was “a rotten

5897.text:
plan, poorly executed”, to quote Max Hastings.
Now, there are a few variations to this somewhat

5903.text:
popular and traditional argument, but the
basic principle is this: the entire Operation

5908.text:
was a failure from its conception. It was
an over-ambitious plan, created in haste by

5913.text:
a poor general, and the major mistakes that
were made, were made mainly by the British

5919.text:
units in the battle, and it was the British
that ultimately should take the blame for

5924.text:
the failure of Operation Market Garden. This
argument makes clear that the ignored intelligence

5930.text:
reports of enemy tanks, the landing zones
miles away from the bridge, not being able

5935.text:
to land the entirety of the Airborne divisions
at once, faulty radios, and a host of bad

5942.text:
decisions by commanders like Horrocks and
Urquhart, essentially proves that the Operation

5947.text:
was poorly executed.
1st Airborne failed to get most of it’s

5951.text:
troops to Arnhem bridge on day 1. They were
too eager to fight the Germans than get to

5957.text:
their objective. They were dropped too far
away from the bridge. Their radios didn’t

5963.text:
work so they became disorganised. XXX Corps
wasn’t hasty enough driving up Hell’s

5968.text:
Highway, especially after getting across Nijmegen
bridge. They delayed when they could have

5972.text:
pressed on towards Arnhem, and may have gotten
to Frost’s men in time. And as General Gavin

5979.text:
of the 82nd said, XXX Corps were 36 hours
delayed before reaching Nijmegen, and as a

5985.text:
result they were never going to get to the
British at Arnhem in time.

5988.text:
For this argument, blame is then usually placed
on one of the British generals. Montgomery,

5993.text:
despised by many people for many different
reasons, often receives criticism for coming

5998.text:
up with this “rotten plan”. Urquhart gets
a lot of criticism for accepting landing zones

6003.text:
miles from Arnhem bridge, and for accompanying
3rd Battalion, slowing them down, and for

6009.text:
getting trapped in a house with his second
in command, and for not making it clear who

6015.text:
would take command of 1st Airborne if he and
Lathbury were lost. So yeah, Urquhart has

6021.text:
his fair share of the blame. Equally, it’s
fair to say that Browning is the one who should

6027.text:
take the blame, since he made plenty of mistakes
too - the most noteworthy of which is dismissing

6033.text:
the intelligence reports of German tanks in
the Arnhem area. But Browning also takes criticism

6038.text:
for taking vital transport aircraft from the
British, and therefore weakening 1st Airborne

6044.text:
on that first vital day. And let’s not forget
Horrocks, who’s slow advance up Hell’s

6050.text:
Highway effectively doomed the Operation,
if you support this argument. XXX Corps took

6055.text:
every opportunity to stop and rest, drink
tea, and generally didn’t perform well at

6060.text:
all. The usual fact that this argument says
is that once the British tanks were over Nijmegen

6063.text:
bridge and the road ahead was clear, they
stayed there and drank tea - despite an American

6069.text:
paratrooper offering to go with them to Arnhem.
So a few variations in who is to blame, but

6074.text:
this argument is the one that’s been ingrained
in the minds of majority of people when they

6079.text:
think about Operation Market Garden. The massively
popular film, “A Bridge Too Far” probably

6085.text:
did more than anything else to cement the
popularity of the argument. A lot of the books

6090.text:
that focus solely on the Arnhem part of the
battlefield tend to agree with this argument

6094.text:
too, because as has been pointed out time
and time again, the British made a lot of

6099.text:
mistakes at Arnhem. So, do you agree with
this argument? Let us know in the comments.

6103.text:
The second argument is that - wait for it
- the Germans were the reason why the Allies

6109.text:
failed. Yes, surprisingly some people think
it wasn’t as much an Allied defeat, as it

6115.text:
was a German victory. Robert Kershaw, in his
book “It Never Snows in September” is

6119.text:
adamant that the Germans outfought the Allies
during Market Garden, despite having to rely

6124.text:
on eyes and ears battalions and other unfit
or reserve units. And when you look at the

6129.text:
evidence, the Germans did a remarkable job
with the little resources they had. All they

6134.text:
had was two depleted Panzer Divisions, not
even at half strength, backed up by Krafft’s

6139.text:
force, which is actually part of 16th Panzergrenadier
Division. So you could make the claim that

6145.text:
there were two and a half panzer divisions
at Arnhem. They also had Panzer Brigade 107,

6150.text:
which successfully harassed the American 101st
Division, and the super successful 406th Division,

6155.text:
that was more of a brigade than a division.
But despite having this severe lack of men

6160.text:
and equipment, the Germans were able to concentrate
the rag-tag forces they had, throw them at

6165.text:
the enemy, and win this battle. Training their
units to fight, rather than march. Improvisation,

6170.text:
and the creation of kampfgruppen - or battle
groups - and the initiative of their leaders,

6176.text:
were the decisive factors that ultimately
allowed the Germans to prevail. Kampfgruppe

6180.text:
Spindler at Arnhem was decisive in stopping
the rest of 1st Airborne reaching Frost at

6186.text:
the Bridge. 10th SS Panzer Division fought
at Nijmegen in a similar situation to Frost

6191.text:
at Arnhem. They delayed XXX Corps at Nijmegen
for 36 hours. It was the Germans who cut the

6197.text:
corridor in the final days of the battle,
and it was the Germans that came to the conclusion

6201.text:
that it wasn’t the British landing zones
being so far from Arnhem that was an issue,

6206.text:
it was “that a second airborne division
was not dropped in the area west of Arnhem”.

6211.text:
This argument raises the question. Was it
more an Allied defeat, or a German victory?

6217.text:
If you support this argument, let us know.
And, the final argument makes the case that

6222.text:
the battle was lost, not at its inception,
not at it’s planning, not even by the Germans

6228.text:
(sort of), but by the decision not to capture
the Nijmegen bridge on day one. This argument

6236.text:
makes the case that the original Market Garden
plan was thrown out as soon as General Gavin

6241.text:
of the 82nd made the decision to deprioritise
the capture of the Nijmegen bridge and focus

6247.text:
his division on the Groesbeek Heights. Without
the capture of Nijmegen bridge, there was

6251.text:
no way XXX Corps could get to Arnhem in time.
Proponents of this argument also make the

6256.text:
case that XXX Corps wasn’t delayed before
they reached Nijmegen, they were delayed 36

6261.text:
hours at Nijmegen. They also point out that
it was Gavin who later claimed XXX Corps was

6266.text:
36 hours behind schedule before reaching Nijmegen
bridge. So basically, because Nijmegen bridge

6272.text:
wasn’t taken on day one, the Germans were
able to block the road to Arnhem, and therefore

6277.text:
the Operation was doomed. It wasn’t that
XXX Corps was too slow as the first argument

6281.text:
suggests, but that they suffered a far too
crucial delay at Nijmegen. The whole point

6287.text:
of the Operation was to lay an airborne carpet
for the tanks to roll over. The bridges were

6293.text:
the priority of the Operation. They were the
main objective. Market Garden failed because

6296.text:
one of those bridges was ignored for a few
hours after the initial landings, allowing

6302.text:
the Germans to secure it. Gavin certainly
comes under flak by supporters of this argument,

6306.text:
since he made the original decision to deprioritise
Nijmegen bridge. But blame also goes to General

6312.text:
Browning, commander of the whole airborne
part of the plan, since his hand was in that

6316.text:
decision too. When asked, who made the decision
to prioritise the Groesbeek Heights rather

6321.text:
than the bridge at Nijmegen, General Gavin’s
response was: This decision was made by myself

6329.text:
and approved by my Corps Commander. As a result,
it’s fair to place the blame on General

6334.text:
Gavin of the US 82nd Airborne, and his superior,
British General Frederick Browning, for the

6338.text:
failure of Operation Market Garden.
So there is a basic overview of the three

6341.text:
main arguments for the failure of Operation
Market Garden. Which do you agree with? Let’s

6345.text:
give you a second to pause the video so you
can let us know your opinion in the comments.

6348.text:
Ok.
Having seen the battle unfold, it’s hard

6350.text:
not to come to the conclusion that the Operation
was lost at Nijmegen. Gavin and Browning failed

6357.text:
to take a bridge, which was the one thing
they had to do. The objective of the whole

6362.text:
Operation was to take the bridges. And they
didn’t do it. And whilst you could say it

6368.text:
was the Germans who held the Nijmegen bridge
for so long, it was only because Gavin didn’t

6373.text:
send troops to take it until the early evening
of the first day, by which point, it was too

6377.text:
late. It’s almost as if it was an afterthought.
There is this fact floating around that XXX

6382.text:
Corps was 36 hours behind schedule by the
time they reached Nijmegen bridge. But this

6386.text:
is actually something Gavin said after the
battle to bend the truth. XXX Corps was at

6391.text:
Nijmegen at the beginning of day 3 of the
Operation. So 42 hours after the beginning

6395.text:
of the Operation (since it started in the
afternoon) they couldn’t be 36 hours behind

6401.text:
schedule, since they were 8 miles from their
objective. They’d gone 50 miles and they’d

6406.text:
got to Nijmegen with time to spare. Unfortunately
not enough spare time to fight the 10th SS

6412.text:
Panzer Division, but if Nijmegen bridge had
been taken by the 82nd, it’s likely they

6417.text:
could have reached Arnhem by the end of day
3.

6420.text:
Because the 82nd hadn’t taken Nijmegen Bridge,
it took XXX Corps and the bravery of the 82nd

6425.text:
troopers paddling across the Waal another
36 hours to get across the bridge. Nijmegen

6430.text:
cost XXX Corps a day and a half, and as a
result, caused Frost’s troops to be overwhelmed,

6436.text:
caused 1st Airborne more casualties, and caused
the failure of the entire Operation. The British

6440.text:
troops at Arnhem were not relieved, and if
they had been on day three, or even on day

6446.text:
four, it’s reasonable to assume that XXX
Corps could have been across the Rhine.

6450.text:
So why didn’t they take Nijmegen bridge
on day one?

6453.text:
The obvious problem was that most of the 82nd
had been ordered to guard the Groesbeek Heights.

6459.text:
Now, you could say that they needed the Heights
as this was their Landing Zone. But the issue

6464.text:
isn’t that they guarded the Landing Zones,
the issue is they guarded the landing zone

6469.text:
with as many troops as they did, and also
flew in artillery to pound the “1000 tanks”

6474.text:
in the Reichswald, rather than take extra
troops that could go towards Nijmegen. And

6478.text:
Warren, who in the end sent 1st Battalion
towards the bridge, wasn’t told to take

6483.text:
Nijmegen bridge until the evening of the first
day. There is a debate, still ongoing, as

6487.text:
to whether Warren was issued pre-drop orders
to take Nijmegen Bridge or not. He insists

6492.text:
that he wasn’t until around 7 or 8pm on
day one. Prior to this, he’d been ordered

6498.text:
to dig in at the Groesbeek Heights, which
he’d done. The blame therefore rests on

6502.text:
General Gavin for not sending anyone towards
Nijmegen.

6506.text:
Because Gavin feared an attack from the 1000
German tanks that were meant to be hiding

6510.text:
in the Reichswald, he placed priority on taking
the Groesbeek Heights, to protect against

6518.text:
their attack. Except there weren’t 1000
tanks in the Reichswald. In fact, there is

6523.text:
no evidence that anyone other than Gavin thought
there were any tanks in the Reichswald. The

6529.text:
German 406th Division that did move out on
day 2 of the Operation could barely be called

6534.text:
a brigade. The first time any German force
worth defending against that was to come from

6539.text:
the Reichswald moved out on Day 4, after XXX
Corps had arrived, and then it wasn’t that

6542.text:
big of a deal. At that point, the battle should
